talk.start.para: —In March 1996, the coalition was elected to government promising leaner, smaller government and promising higher standards and honesty. Having attacked the National Media Liaison Service when in opposition, they immediately and secretly established a taxpayer funded Australia wide media monitoring unit—a unit whose total annual salary costs alone now approach $1 million. I have spoken previously about the secretive and dishonest manner in which this unit was established.

speech.para: But the government's hypocrisy in relation to the size of these units does not end with the baby aNiMaLS. On 12 April 1996 they set up the government members secretariat with an initial establishment of 10 positions. Nine positions were immediately filled and no advertisements were placed by the Department of Administrative Services.

The government has tried to draw a comparison between the role and scope of the government members secretariat and the government caucus committees secretariat that serviced Labor backbenchers when we were in government. This is an extremely dishonest comparison. For a start, the caucus committee secretariat had an establishment of six. It employed one director, four clerks and a personal secretary, and provided administrative and secretarial support to backbench and caucus committees. The classification levels of the staff reflected the support nature of its work. The government members secretariat, on the other hand, is top-heavy. Its current establishment of 11 is composed of a senior adviser, four advisers, four assistant advisers and two personal secretaries. The total estimated cost of the staff salaries alone exceeds three-quarters of a million dollars.

But it is not only the cost or the high classification staff levels which makes a comparison with the caucus committees secretariat inappropriate. Rather, it is the overtly political nature of the work that the government members secretariat performs that makes its taxpayer funded existence so offensive. The opposition has no problem with the employment of staff under the MOPS Act in a manner that provides a government wide service to MPs. The role of such units, however, should have a parliamentary or an executive or ministerial focus. In any event, they should not have an exclusively campaigning role. This is the task of party secretariats.

The preparation of shell newsletters, political pamphlets, the provision of technical support for party databases and the production of message documents are not the functions of taxpayer funded staff; they are the responsibility of party funded operatives. It is Menzies House, John McEwen House or, for that matter, the ALP's national secretariat which should bear the responsibility and the cost for such material.

So how does the government describe the functions and responsibilities of the government members secretariat? In answers to questions asked during the senate estimates process, the weasel words that have been used have been to say that the GMS:
assists members and senators in communicating government decisions, policies and programs or dealing with issues which are frequently raised within electorate offices or are of relevance to electors.

What this translates to is simple. The government has established a taxpayer funded political unit worth three-quarters of a million dollars in salaries alone to conduct marginal seat campaigning. What we have with the government members secretariat is a support unit for Robert Menzies House. It is a marginal seats campaigning unit—a top-heavy political hit squad that performs year-round campaigning for the coalition in marginal seats across Australia.

The cost to the taxpayer of this political campaigning unit does not end with the salaries of the staff involved. The savings to Robert Menzies House and the National Party headquarters are worth well over $1 million per annum when other state-of-the-art equipment is taken into account. The costs blow out even more when the extensive travel of the staff of the government members secretariat is taken into account.

In equipment alone, we know the GMS has eight mobile phones. In February 1997 it had four laptop computers. Since then, four more have been purchased. As well as 10 conventional desktop computers, the GMS has videos, TVs and colour printers, at least two photocopiers, three fax machines, desktop publishing facilities, a folding machine and a scanner.

We also know that the joint house committee has carried out $40,000 worth of fit-out changes to the offices occupied by the GMS since they were located there. We know that the senior adviser, Mr Chris Fryar, who has operational command of the unit, receives a vehicle supplied on usual SES level terms and conditions. The cost of the equipment is all met by the taxpayer. The cost of maintaining the equipment and the ongoing costs of the phones and photocopiers are also met by the taxpayer. Even the cost of the extensive newspaper subscription received by the GMS is met by the taxpayer.

We know that in calendar year 1997 the GMS spent an incredible $33,464 on station ery alone. But the taxpayer funded costs do not end there. Will the government confirm that Ms Sue Warren, a former employee of the GMS, who is now employed on the personal staff of the Leader of the Government in the Senate as a political adviser, actually produces weekly newsletters that are attributed to the GMS? If this is the case, this adds at least one functional staff member at adviser level to the staff establishment of the GMS.

We know that two of the staff are not Canberra based. Ms Aileen Wiesner, an assistant adviser, is based in Sydney in the office of the Prime Minister, while Mr Keith Blyth, an adviser, is based in Adelaide in the office of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Mr Blyth's trips to Canberra have therefore cost the taxpayer $32,367.80 in airfares alone since his appointment. This does not include the cost of cabcharge or travel allowance.

In Ms Wiesner's case, her 55 domestic airfares between Canberra and Sydney since her appointment, worth $8,338.40, are nothing compared to the real costs that she has incurred taxpayers. In addition to her commercial airfares, in 1996 alone she travelled an additional 16 times between Canberra and Sydney on VIP aircraft. From April 1996, when the unit was established, to May 1998, the airfares and car transport of the GMS staff have totalled $185,259. This figure does not include VIP travel or the cost of the tax free travel allowance paid to staff.

If the government is comfortable that this travel has always constituted a legitimate expense by staff members of the GMS, then they should come into this chamber and explain why Mr Brendan Cooper, a personal secretary at the GMS, was required to travel extensively between Canberra and Perth in October, November and December, 1996. Can the government assure us that he was not deployed as a political operative for the state election then being conducted in Western Australia? Did he claim travelling allowance when he visited Perth during this time or was he on unpaid leave? If he did not receive travel allowance and if he was on unpaid leave, what justification is there for his taxpayer funded flights worth almost $10,000 to provide political support for the re-election of the Court Liberal government in Western Australia?

Is it a coincidence that Mr Brendan Cooper resigned from the GMS on 3 October, 1997 to take up a position with Mr Court, the Premier of Western Australia? Indeed, what were Mr Cooper's political responsibilities that required him to take almost $50,000 worth of commercial air travel alone during his time at the GMS?

Ms Linda Reynolds, an adviser with the GMS since its establishment, is described as the senior training coordinator. Why was she conveniently required in Western Australia continuously for 18 days during the period of the Western Australia state election? Will the government assure the Senate that her activities did not in any way relate to the state election campaign?

Supplying equipment to MOPS staff is not inappropriate. Paying the travel costs to the same staff is not inappropriate. However, the issue in this instance is: should the cost of the activities of the GMS be met by the taxpayer or by the coalition parties who, like the Labor Party, receive public funding for the legitimate costs of federal campaigning at elections? The simple fact is that the equivalent activities of the GMS were always performed by the national secretariat of the ALP or its various state and territory branches when we were in government and that is still the case now that we are in opposition. None of us in this chamber are political babes in the woods. We know what goes on. All of us know approximately where the line falls between the tasks that can be performed by taxpayer-funded staff and party political staff.

The GMS is beyond the pale. It is a campaigning tool, pure and simple. It serves no other role than that of marginal seats campaigning on behalf of the parties. As far as we can ascertain, the GMS does not serve any single function which should be legitimately borne by the taxpayer.

This is not an argument about the balance between opposition and government staff. It is an argument about the proper function of the government staff. If the opposition were to close its eyes to the activities of the GMS, it would be to ignore forever the distinction that has traditionally existed, at least in a practical sense, between the staff of parties and the staff of parliamentarians.

What exactly does the government members secretariat produce? We know that they produce `Points of order' which is subtitled, `A daily summary of proceedings in Parliament House, Canberra.' It is a message document that contains, in point form, bullet point messages, lines and so-called facts to assist coalition campaigners in determining appropriate political lines.

We know that they provide training support that includes the use of database programs within electorate offices. This technical support is coordinated by Mr Tim Archer, an assistant adviser at the GMS, whose actual role is national database trainer. This almost certainly includes the Liberal Party's feedback program, which is their direct mail database.

I would note that members and senators now receive a separate software allowance to defray the cost of technical support and training for such databases. Surely Mr Tim Archer's activities should not be charged to taxpayers. There is no justification at all for the taxpayer subsidising Mr Archer's blatant political activities.

We know that they have received Corel Draw 7, which is used as the desktop publishing program to produce shell newsletters. The artwork is provided directly to government members and senators. I would point out that Corel Draw 7 is not even available in the offices of senators and members and that, therefore, material provided in this format must be passed on to a professional printer before it can be utilised by parliamentarians.

If the function of the GMS is, as stated, to provide training and support to coalition parliamentarians and to ensure the efficient and effective operation of electorate offices, how can the provision of material that is not even compatible with the software in their offices be consistent with this? This is simply taxpayer funded, cradle to grave election material.

The shell newsletters and pamphlets are not of the information variety that are often produced in members' offices. They are political propaganda—dirt sheets on the Labor Party and overt political promotion of the policies and the themes of the coalition government.

We have seen their small business newsletter, their notes on tax and debt and their material on the unfair dismissals legislation. Some of the material has been found to breach the Electoral Act because it has not been correctly authorised. The member for Dunkley, Mr Bruce Billson, distributed a GMS small business newsletter which fell foul of the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act because it had not been correctly authorised.

Other activities have been found to be unscrupulous or dishonest, such as the letter writing campaign where coalition members were encouraged to submit letters to the editor under their own signatures that had in fact been drafted elsewhere.

At the outset, I referred to the government's hypocrisy about size of government and the promise of higher standards. By `higher standards' the government presumably meant honesty and accountability. We have already seen the dishonesty that surrounded the secret establishment of a nationwide media monitoring unit with no line item appropriation. The opposition, therefore, found it extremely difficult to effectively question ministers and officials about the costs and function of the media monitoring unit during Senate estimates hearings. In the same way, the government has sought to prevent questions being raised about the government members secretariat.

When it was originally established, the GMS was responsible to the Minister for Administrative Services and questions could be addressed to the minister during Senate estimates in the ordinary fashion. Recently, however, the GMS has been transferred from DAS to the chief government whip, Neil Andrew MP, in an attempt to prevent parliamentary scrutiny. We know the GMS services both senators and members. What possible reason, other than a shady attempt to invoke the principle of comity between the two chambers, can be advanced for this transfer to an office holder of the House of Represen tatives? This is simply an attempt to prevent Senate estimates scrutiny of the unit's activities.

We know that the salary costs are in the order of $760,000 per annum, including ministerial staffing allowance. We know that the annualised stationery costs are worth about $33,000 and that the annual costs of airfares and car transport exceed $92,000. The GMS has over $54,000 worth of equipment, and it spent $40,000 on office renovations. We know that their franking machine has thousands of dollars worth of postage on it. We have no estimate of the travelling allowance paid to staffers, or the costs of VIP and other non-standard airfares. We do not know the costs of the facilities provided to staffers based outside Canberra or the true costs of staffers who work for the GMS but are not part of their official establishment.

We can be certain that the costs would easily exceed $1 million per annum, combined with baby aNiMaLS, which also spends almost $1 million on salaries alone. The government is spending $2.5 million on these two units alone—$2.5 million dollars to employ and deploy 24 full-time—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —A Victoria Cross is displayed in the National Party party room in Parliament House. The Victoria Cross is the supreme military honour. It represents great courage against greater odds and the strength to overcome fear and to act positively for the sake of your country and your children. That Victoria Cross was won by an officer, Mr Anderson, who went on to become the Country Party member for Hume.

speech.para: I raise this today as a reminder of the legacy of heroes of the past who kept Australia safe and free. I raise it to demonstrate a patriotism that is tangible and real. There are some people in this country who use the cloak of patriotism to cover a lack of substance; there are some people who declare their patriotism rather than their agenda. One Nation wanted the world to believe they were patriots, so they claimed the support of a VC winner. But the VC did not exist. It was all a sham.

The rise of One Nation has posed challenges for us all: politicians, political parties, the media and the people. Firstly, I affirm that the coalition must continually strive to give strong leadership to rural Australia, despite the National Party's small proportion of the parliament and an obstructive Senate. Strong leadership involves three things: policy action, being a good messenger and courage.

In the two years since we came to power, the coalition government has put over $1 billion into major policy actions for rural Australia, above and beyond the traditional portfolio requirements—and this in a tight fiscal environment. The coalition has listened to the fallout from competition policy with concessions to pharmacists, newsagents and the sugar industry. We may have to do more.

Thousands of farming families survived the drought only through years of government assistance, including a further 12 months after the drought to help them back on their feet. Drought funding of $620 million has been provided to farm families over the past six years. That is a lot of listening.

The coalition government is prepared to go to the ballot box in a difficult electoral climate to get the issue of native title resolved. There can be no greater sign of our commitment to rural towns, industries, employment, infrastructure and diversification. Did we not listen to the sounds of rural and small business backs breaking under high interest rates? Now the farm sector saves between $400 million and $500 million a year through lower interest rates, which is an average benefit of $600,000 per farmer. Did we not also listen to the cries for help to get our products into overseas markets to help the four out of five primary producers who rely on exports? Yes, we listened and we delivered. Yes, there is more to do. There will always be more to do.

Remember that One Nation has a vested interest in drowning out the achievements and complexities of government. I talked about the need for courage. That means a firm hand on the tiller—not lurching to the right or to the left but holding out for what is practical and beneficial for our people. If these are hard times for the National Party, then these are dangerous times for rural Australians. It is more important than ever that the National Party dare mightily in both acting for our people and in exposing the chill desert winter offered by One Nation.

Some say we should move to the right and vacate the conservative moderate ground, leave the coalition, print more money, raise tariffs, go back to the White Australia policy—where would that thinking end? How far would fear, once given into, chase us? This is the kind of hard time when leaders must act—not out of fear but out of the courage to say what is right and true and to defend that truth against great odds.

For a long time, the far right have searched for a perfect political foil, an anti-politician who can attract wave after wave of publicity. They tried it with Peter Sawyer, the Logos Foundation and Graeme Campbell. They finally hit the ballot box office with the One Nation leader. The message is centuries old and plays on our fears and disappointments. They tell us we are all doomed to endless poverty and that the major parties are selling us out as part of a foreign conspiracy intent on world domination.

The ageless modus operandi of the extreme right is to massage their message so it is plausible and simple. Their sympathisers and fellow travellers then move in to back an isolated person capable of using ordinariness as a political weapon. That person gradually becomes surrounded with people and ideas that flatter and seem to help but, behind the scenes, contacts are made which inevitably lead back into the extremist networks.

Their approach is recognisable. They enlarge some of society's problems and make up others. Many want to believe that the hard bits of life are someone's fault. The finger is pointed at scapegoats who can be easily identified either because they are in public life, they look different or they practise a different religion. Distil the message of One Nation today and you have the same themes as the League of Rights had five, 25 and 50 years ago: fortress Australia, anti-immigration, Aboriginal welfare, secret international plans and community referenda. The big difference today is that the package is updated and the organisation more professional.

I do not know a single person who has not suffered in this life—this is reality—and no government, no political party, can take away all unhappiness. I know very well that the bush has done it tough. Together we have tried to work through solutions on big and small issues, from native title and Hilmer to a single word on a label that is causing problems. It has been my privilege to be their voice. My remarks about One Nation today reflect not on regional Australians but on those few, those very few, who use them to scavenge some much needed credibility.

I am proud to stand by my record as a practical politician who has had wins and quite a few bruises from fighting for the bush. Acting on principle, I have crossed the floor on both rural and family value issues. I have made the real difference that can only come through parliamentary forums and processes—not through treating parliament with contempt, running away from the tough questions and resorting to shallow generalisations.

Like the Australians who won the Victoria Cross, we must stand up to those who would put our future at risk. This is difficult. It is much easier for all of us to surrender to the mirage of short-term gain—politicians, media and the people. One Nation cannot trust their members to run the party in a democratic Australian way. So they made it a private company, run by a triumvirate and sealed with a secret pact. One Nation uses fear, not fact, to engage on a purely emotional level.

But for Australians to go forward we need hearts and minds to work together energised by hope and not negativity. Our vision must be based on the practical reason that we have to trade to survive, not turn our backs on the world. A very famous Australian once said:

This small population, located at so vast a difference from other civilised parts of the globe, can have no prospect of success unless it can raise the export of some raw material in considerable demand . . . and be capable of bearing the expense for the longest sea voyage.

Those were the words of John Macarthur in the 18th century. His vision then holds true today. We have to be a trading nation. Macar thur pioneered the wool industry thereby enabling Australia to stand on its own without handouts from Britain. If we lose the essence of that vision now as One Nation wants, then our children will be like the early settlers—eking out a welfare existence. If we resorted to printing money, it would soon cease to have value. The early settlers traded in rum after all.

Like other subversive political movements which seek to destroy rather than to build, the rise of One Nation has encouraged a new kind of political correctness. The word `global' is code for sinister international forces. Surely if Macarthur could start a huge industry with six sheep and a vision based on the `globe', we cannot go too far wrong. Thanks to One Nation, the word `immigration' now resonates with fear and suspicion. The term `politician' is the lowest of the low in the One Nation syntax, despite the fact that they all want to be one. `Aborigine' in One Nation lingo has become synonymous with the welfare aristocracy. They tie first with Asians as the people most to blame for the mess the country is apparently in. The code word of One Nation makes a rotten language that does not judge people on their merits but on the colour of their skin or the place of their origin. This is not how the Victoria Cross was won.

It is said that the vote for One Nation was a protest vote and nothing to do with its policies. Policy scrutiny has long been a hallmark of Australian political life. This used to ensure that hypocrisy and policy nonsense were exposed. We all have responsibilities in a democracy. I have to say that One Nation and its leaders have not been brought to account. This was not helped by One Nation cutting short its policy media launch after 10 minutes, but it was a particular problem in regional areas where local media releases are often reprinted verbatim without the analysis and probing we expect ritually here. I was not alone in being stunned by the happy family types of reporting on One Nation in the Queensland election. Regional Queensland was fed a regular diet of positive One Nation profiles. The commendable exception to this was Queensland Country Life which exposed the dangers of One Nation policies to primary producers.

How many voters last Saturday were aware that, despite One Nation's emphasis on law and order and their call for greater police powers, the One Nation leader voted against the government to make it more difficult for law enforcement agencies to get warrants for phone taps? Where was the headline `One Nation helps crime bosses'? How many voters in Queensland knew that, despite One Nation's call to abolish native title and benefits based on race, the One Nation leader voted to give millions of acres of Queensland crown land in freehold to Aboriginal land councils using a native title regime based on non-extinguishment?

These actions are totally at odds with other statements by the leader and the One Nation Party. Yet there was no call to account and no headline that said `One Nation leader says give land to Aborigines'. There was no exposure of the facts that the party leader said one thing and did another. These votes are significant because the One Nation leader actually attended them. We must conclude that they helped somehow in her stated mission to `make a difference'. One Nation also has a policy for politicians to have equivalent remuneration common to all other workers. I am still waiting to hear whether the One Nation leader has deposited a large chunk of her above average income into a charity account. Perhaps she is planning to lend it out at two per cent.

How many Queensland voters were aware that the new One Nation Queensland president, Tom King, believes that Australia has global parks owned by the United Nations where foreigners can go but we cannot? King has taken his conspiracies to the readers of both the Strategy and the League of Rights publication On Target. How many know that this One Nation boss portrayed himself falsely as part of the mainstream Australian Defence Association and advertised himself publicly as such in the Strategy? This paper's favourite themes are one world government conspiracies and anti-Semitism. Advertisers include the League of Rights and the extremist magazine Lock, Stock and Barrel, which has had some editions banned. How many knew that the Strategy, which has several links to One Nation, sponsored the Australian tour of a prominent American militiaman, Jack McLamb?

There is a vast virtual world of One Nation on the Internet, but how many voters in Queensland knew that One Nation web master and official biographer, Scott Balson, has a business arrangement with the same extremist newspaper, the Strategy? Balson gives them double billing with his own news of the day service. Together they form the Independents Consortium. Where was the headline `One Nation spins racist web'? This is virtual politics, where reality is buried deep beneath hundreds of pages of propaganda and mixed media wizardry.

How many Queenslanders knew that One Nation strategist and would-be senator David Oldfield visited known extremists for input to gun and immigration policy to get their networks on side? One of these, Ron Owen, editor of Lock, Stock and Barrel, has promoted the violent white Afrikaner resistance in his magazine and suggested that readers send them money. These far right links to One Nation will only increase. A federal candidate in New South Wales has been connected with the AUSI Freedom Scouts and Campbell's Australia First Party. One of the Scouts's adds in Lock, Stock and Barrel claims that our air and water were deliberately poisoned. `Take our weapons,' they state, `and we will take your life.'

A candidate in Victoria Tony Peters has called for a royal commission into the Port Arthur massacre. He has been taken in by the Strategy line that it was all a conspiracy and that Martin Bryant is innocent. Another One Nation officer Tony Pitt promotes this view too. Do they really say what all Australians think? Robyn Spencer founded Australians Against Further Immigration. She has now taken over the reins of One Nation in Victoria and written their immigration policy. The Age recently reported that Oldfield brokered a deal for 500 AAFI Victorian members to move into One Nation ranks. In return, Spencer would get the top spot on the One Nation Senate ticket.
Who are these people taking over One Nation? They do not have ordinary ideas. The AAFI have close links with the League of Rights. One of their candidates said:
My policy on refugees and illegals is to reopen the second Yallah meatworks, creating up to 500 local jobs, and convert them to blood and bone.

Robyn Spencer has direct links with the League of Rights. She addressed a regional dinner of the League of Rights in Victoria in May 1995. League founder, Eric Butler, reported the occasion in the league newsletter, finishing with the statement:

If the AAFI can elect only a handful of senators at the next federal election, perhaps holding the balance of power, they may be the decisive factor . . . Every social creditor should be able to grasp this potential and to act accordingly.

Social credit is the ancestor of One Nation's financial policies. The league promoted a tape of Ms Spencer's address. She went on to share a platform with Eric Butler at another league meeting—the annual dinner in Adelaide in August 1995. The AAFI is also home to Denis McCormack, another speaker at the League of Rights, proofreader of the One Nation leader's book, adviser to Graeme Campbell, and Vice President of Graeme Campbell's Australia First Party.

The umbrella of One nation shelters the ragtag army of the far right. This is very serious. We are witnessing a steady amalgamation of the far right groups under the One Nation banner. Decent Queenslanders registering a protest vote would be horrified at the agendas of these extremist groups—would be horrified at how deep their claws have sunk into One Nation. The bottom line for the league is that they blame the Jews for everything—wars and depressions. They deny the Jewish holocaust. They say it was a bad case of typhoid. They say Hitler's policy was a Jewish policy. They argue that Jesus Christ was not a Jew. That is the ugly hidden reality of the League of Rights and their fellow travellers. But Queensland never knew. The media made the public face of One Nation widely acceptable by failing to expose the unacceptable.

It is not good enough to mention these serious defects in political character in a small par on page 10, if at all, while large photos and happy family reports are on page 1. Profile is votes. More profile is more votes. What possible conclusion could the reader reach but that the strange links mean little against the earnest smile on a One Nation face and empty platitudes?

Economic rationalism must be taking its toll in the press galleries. No-one has the time to do investigative research. A free press has to be a responsible press. What message is sent to those wanting to enter political life—that they should criticise Asians, hardly ever attend parliament, get a lot of facts wrong, sign up some key extremist networks and smile for the camera? That may be the make-believe world of virtual politics, but it is not the real politics. I know that it is not the kind of leadership that makes a difference or creates one new job.

The Victoria Cross in our party room was not won by taking the easy path. It was not won by shadow-boxing; it was won by an encounter with grim reality. The National Party's VC is a real VC. It was won by a real hero who chose hope, valour and hard work over fear and running away from the real issues. I know that in the end Australia will choose that way too.

talk.start.para: —The appropriation bills that we are being asked to look at are: Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1998-99 , moneys for ordinary annual services of the government; Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1998-99 , moneys for non-recurrent expenditure; and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1998-99 , money for departments. These bills, unfortunately, are another example of ignorant, ideological and misguided legislation reflecting ignorant, ideological and misguided policies of this government which this government is hell bent on pursuing. It is no wonder that the fervent and impassioned speech we have just heard is now belatedly necessary in this parliament when this government has been pursuing scapegoat politics through their policies.

speech.para: This government is hell bent on pursuing economic rationalism at any cost, and then finding someone else to blame for the out comes. It is hell bent on believing that the famous hand of the market can deliver all the goodies we have ever wanted as a country. It is hell bent on applying competition policy ad nauseam to all aspects of society. The Nationals, who are now leaving the chamber I notice, themselves were concerned about competition policy but did not stand up against either the Labor Party or the coalition in administering it at all costs. This government is hell bent on the free trade agenda at any cost to our local industries and our unemployment levels. Behind these appropriation bills we see a government hell bent on achieving a surplus at any cost.

This government is not interested in looking at any real indications of the well-being of our society. They are happy to hide behind their nice bottom line and ignore the reality in our society: the sickening reality that the quality of health in Australia is spiralling down; the informed reality that education is moving towards a framework where universities are a business, students are customers and those students whose mummy and daddy can pay will get top notch education; the desperate reality that our unemployment rate is not getting better; the unjust reality that people who desperately need legal representation cannot afford it; and the intolerant reality that people are so disillusioned, frustrated and angry that they are looking for racist and selfish answers—the kind that we saw responded to today.

If the government decided to pull its head out of the sand, if the hypnotic effect of the budget surplus wore off, I would submit that unemployment levels are a good place to start in looking for real indications of Australia's well-being. With Japan, the United States, the Netherlands and Switzerland all on an unemployment rate of below five per cent, it is clear that there is a long way to go before Australia should receive pats on the back on the basis of this economic indicator.

The Queensland election drove home a crystal clear message. It is not that there are a heap of rednecks in Queensland who are anti-Aboriginal and anti-immigration—no. The crystal clear message is that the community is sick and tired of being ruled by testosterone-charged bottom liners. People are sick of being dictated to by economists who value a balanced budget more than they value quality health care, quality education and removing unemployment. In fact, unemployment at a highish level is desired by many large corporations investing in a country like Australia. They are downright sick of the government saying that economic rationalism and free trade are the only way to go, regardless of how it affects Mr and Ms Joe Citizen. Remember that exports are only about 20 per cent of Australia's economy. We have forgotten about our domestic economy.

The Australian community are crying out through the ballot box for the government to hear their concerns. They are crying out through the ballot box for the government to acknowledge that people in Australia are hurting, even though the media and the economists gave an almost unanimous pat on the back for bringing home a surplus. The people of Australia are not impressed by a surplus when they can see the real impacts on the ground. They can see that the dogged pursuit of the bottom line has destroyed communities and is still doing so. They have had enough of head-in-the-cloud economists ruling their lives. They have had enough of money markets in Europe and the United States running their lives. Australians are refusing to listen to the prevailing wisdom that anyone who disagrees with the government's economic orthodoxy is some kind of economic nobody, an illiterate economic lightweight. They have said, `Enough is enough.'

There is a vote from the people on the ground that this government's pursuit of a surplus at all costs has had devastating impacts from a social perspective. What has been less widely acknowledged is that the economic benefits of a budget in surplus are in fact highly dubious. The surplus, as an indication of economic wellbeing, has been beefed up beyond belief. Many other economic indicators are telling a very different story and they suggest that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) should be chastised and not congratulated.

The government's blase attitude to the ever-widening current account deficit is especially disturbing. Not only are they complacent about the fact that the current account deficit is ballooning, but they are trying to shove it under the carpet by saying, `Don't worry about the current account deficit. Our public sector finances are A-OK, so we can ride this wave.' Even Senator Cook, from the opposition, the other day was saying, `Look how many more exports we've got.' He forgot to mention that there are many more imports—more than we have exported. So in fact we are running faster and faster and not even staying in the same place.

This is the general smoke and mirrors approach that the coalition have taken to all the economic indicators that point to the fact that their approach to economics may not be as hot to trot as they claim. The Treasurer tried to talk up the Aussie dollar as it plunged to deeper and deeper levels, again saying, `But, hey, we produced a surplus. She'll be right, mate.' The biggest concern I have with the Treasurer's blase attitude towards the current account deficit is that his comments echo exceptionally problematic reasoning.

The coalition's attitudes and claims are based on the concept of the twin deficit theory. The twin deficit theory is based on a link between budget deficits and surpluses and the current account deficit or surplus. The reliance on the twin deficit theory is evident in statements in budget paper No. 1 of 1998-99, which states:
. . . the ongoing improvement in public sector finances should exert a downward pressure on the current account deficit.

The idea of the twin deficit theory has never been borne out in practice, however. Indeed, it is clear that the twin deficit theory is a fallacy when you consider that, firstly, across all countries the current account deficit must sum to zero and, secondly, in contrast, government deficits across all countries can take on a large range of values. The twin deficit fallacy is overwhelmingly illustrated by the latest current account figures. Despite moves towards a budget surplus over the last two years, our current account deficit has continued to increase. Could it be that they are not related?

The government has had its head in the clouds. The current account deficit is a crucial economic indicator of wellbeing. It is not the be-all and end-all, but it is crucial. It reflects the state of the national economy and deserves serious attention. To think that all will be A-OK, irrespective of the current account deficit, as long as the domestic export fundamentals are kept under control is naivety in the extreme. People in the community can sense this. They know what is happening with local industries. They know how much they can buy that is made elsewhere. They can even see those things which are food commodities in the marketplace. It is obvious to everyone except the government and perhaps the opposition.

The Greens (WA) are disappointed with a wide range of areas in this budget. Let us start with health and community services, as health care is a relevant place to start. There is no Commonwealth funding for dental care for low income people; no new initiatives in child care, despite ripping out operational subsidies for community based child-care facilities; and no new capital for aged care, despite pleas from the carers in this area who can see that the quality is sinking and sinking as the operators of residential aged care facilities are penny-pinching, cost cutting and staff slashing. The offer in the Australian health care agreement was so low that even the conservative states walked out. There was not one extra dollar to help the public hospital system in crisis, and we have the poorly targeted extension of the seniors health care card.

In relation to taxation, we have increases in migration charges to $5,000 for parents and the introduction of discriminatory visa fees. In relation to labour market programs, there was a further reduction in resources for employment assistance services as a result of savings made through the much advertised Job Network competitive tendering process, where the government is walking away from its responsibility. We have a further tightening of the activity test for unemployed people. Blame the unemployed: that takes the pressure off government.

Let us look at welfare recipients, a big target of the government. We have further pain and a further tightening of the belts of those who can least afford it. There were reduced entitlements affecting many sole parents, including cuts to parenting payments for indigenous sole parents participating in the community development employment program. Blame the unemployed. Blame the poor. Take the pressure off yourself. We have reductions in pensioner education supplements for those not carrying a full study load and a reduction in family allowance for some receiving non-cash maintenance.

For women, we have an emphasis on a gender neutral mainstreaming approach to policy initiatives that have an impact on women. We have no new initiatives for women. In housing, we have the continued decline in funding of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement from 1996-97 levels, including a five per cent dividend cut and an annual cut of $50 million. Again, the government is pulling out the basic necessities and reducing the fundamental standard of living.

Under law and justice, we have no new funds for legal aid and tighter guidelines for spending that will diminish access to legal aid for migration and refugee matters in the Federal Court and the High Court. We have a total undermining of the idea that everyone is equal before the law—the bedrock of the rule of law. This government is positively usurping this principle by saying everyone who can afford it is equal before the law. We have a tighter application requirement and higher fees for refugee applicants in their processes. Is that fair, I ask you?

All in all, these appropriation bills are inadequate. There is not enough funding to address the deep social problems, the ever increasing number of people living in poverty, the continued degradation of the environment, and the desperate situation in the bush. The little electioneering sweeteners that the Treasurer has passed out to the Australian people will not fool them. They feel the impacts of this famous, or now infamous, surplus every day.

In conclusion, I would like to say that this is a government that has used its economic policies as a process of blame. Punish those people who have the least ability to fight back. Reduce funds to those people who are cited as being the noisy lobby groups that even One Nation cites. It is a good way of pretending that you are not going along with bigoted policies by targeting particular groups of people and silencing, as we have heard in the last week or so, those groups who dare to speak out and advise on the policies and the impacts on real people—the impacts not just in rural and regional Australia but on anyone who does not fit under somebody's strange idea of average.

This is what we are seeing in these appropriation bills. Unless Australia sees a real desire to look at the impact of these policies of economic rationalism on the ground, this government obviously does not really want to learn why Australians are disenfranchised.

talk.start.para: —The appropriation bills for 1998-99 were touted by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) to put Australia back in the black, back on track. What he did not indicate, however, was what track he was talking about, whether it was the track from Darwin to Alice Springs or the railway track from Melbourne to Darwin via every marginal seat in the country.

speech.para: What they actually do, however, is cause more pain and hardship to ordinary Australians who thought that, by voting for the coalition, they were voting for a fairer Australia, a government for all of us. In reality, the burdens placed on these Australians—the elderly, the unemployed, our rural and regional Australians and our young people—are now almost unbearable. The government will have you believe that all this pain was essential. The people of Queensland demonstrated on 13 June, however, that they are not copping the pain any more, and I think they spoke, in all probability, for most Australians.

If it was essential, why did this budget contain spending increases of $10 billion over the next four years? If it was essential, why is it that, when we look at the effect on financial year 1998-99 of the three Costello budgets, we find that, in net terms, he cut $6 billion in the first budget, $1 billion in the second and then put back $2 billion in the third?

The government has turned its back on older Australians, who, even after the nursing home entry fee debacle last year, still have to pay up to $4,380 in annual fees and up to $37.65 in extra daily fees. In their hour of their greatest fragility, they are still having to sell the family home to pay for entry into a nursing home. After all the backflips and reversals—some 14 of them in all—the fees remain, and the government still circles the family homes of our elderly.

With all the debate going on over child care—there was an interesting series in the Sydney Morning Herald earlier last week on the changes that have been wrought in this area—the government failed again to rectify their meanness by allocating no additional funding for child care in this budget. The budget papers showed that expenditure on child-care assistance is down by $117 million, because parents simply cannot afford formal care any longer. Women are being forced back into the home, or children are being placed in backyard care. Since the 1996 election, almost $1 billion has vanished from child-care funding, which says it all about the current government.

The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, thinks about family values, but these changes amount to a collapse in the living standards of middle and low income working families. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) said in his speech in reply:

These are the human losses on which this accountants' surplus was built by a government that has long since ceased caring and has never learned to care. These indeed are the hard yards. These are the long hauls. The shouldered burden of battling Australians somehow fuels the happiness of a Treasurer long unacquainted with the ordinary needs of his fellow Australians. The griefs and consolations and the quiet unprotested sufferings underpin the triumph of his numbers and the failure of his government's decency.

So what we see from this government is a general lack of direction, of substance and of innovative and worthwhile programs across all sections of our society, industry and economy. I want to focus on today a number of issues that affect all Australians.

Research and development in Australian industry has been let down by the Howard government. Throughout the course of this government, the Howard led coalition has cut $2.2 billion to industrial research and development assistance. Over $2 billion has been torn out of R&D programs over the life of the current government and replaced with much smaller R&D incentives. Last year's budget papers set aside $164 million for R&D grants in 1997-98, but only $109 million was actually spent. This government program is in deep trouble 18 months after it was launched.

Was this $55 million that was saved rolled over into the budget for R&D for the following year? No, it was not. Did it go back to Treasury and into consolidated revenue? No, it did not. In the estimates hearings for the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism on 2 June, we heard that the money was used to offset some other programs within the industry portfolio. Money that should have been spent on Australian research and development was spent in other areas.

The massive fall-off in R&D start funding has been caused by Australian businesses rejecting the complex and bureaucratic structures set up under the program. This is coupled with the fact that the government is being particularly nasty in its approach to R&D funding, as the policies are designed to cut its budget rather than pick the best available job-generating projects which have obvious flow-on effects. If the Prime Minister were serious about Australian research and development, he would have ensured that the full underspend was rolled over into the next financial year. In fact, he would ensure that the program for R&D expenditure is capable of being met in full in each financial year.

However, it is not only in the area of research and development that the Australian people have been let down. The Prime Minister made an election promise to create 200,000 new manufacturing jobs by the year 2000. The only jobs promise he made during the last election campaign is now absolutely in tatters. By now, he should have created 102,500 new manufacturing jobs. Instead, there has been a net loss of manufacturing jobs in the Australian economy. Just last week, data released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed the continuation of the collapse of Australian manufacturing jobs. Labour force selected summary tables for May 1998 show a seasonally adjusted fall of 2,300 manufacturing jobs in the quarter to May 1998.

In total, over the last year, 32,900 manufacturing jobs have been lost, with falls occurring in each of the last three quarters. Given that the Prime Minister has not been able to meet the only jobs promise in his election campaign of 1996, I am sure that it can be justified by simply putting it into the category of non-core promises. It will go with the long list of promises that this government has failed to meet in terms of the commitments it made to the Australian people at the last election.

The reality is that the Howard government has no positive strategy to achieve jobs growth. Without this, however, the future for Australian workers is bleak. Unfortunately, there are still no signs that the government has recognised the need for such a strategy, which is cold comfort for all the remaining manufacturing workers. There are certainly no positive indicators of this in these appropriations. In fact, there has been an alarming slump in expenditure in the manufacturing sector over the last quarter, which is strong evidence of the manufacturing industry's lack of confidence in the policies of the Howard government.

Australian Bureau of Statistics data on private new capital expenditure and expected expenditure to June 1999, released on 20 May 1998, shows that spending in manufacturing has fallen from $3,064 million in the December 1997 quarter to $2,575 million in the March 1998 quarter, which is the lowest level of expenditure since March 1997. Those figures are hardly surprising. The Howard government has presided over a decline in growth, an ever-expanding current account deficit, an ever-growing foreign debt, and an unemployment rate that is stuck at around eight per cent with no real hope of decreasing in the short term.

One of the main causes of slower growth is budget decisions taken by the Costello-Howard government that have put a stop to growth in innovation in industry. Business confidence simply is not there. The ACCI-Westpac industrial trends report for the June quarter states that those firms expecting an improvement in general business conditions in the next six months fell from 16 per cent to six per cent while those predicting a deterioration rose from 35 per cent to 57 per cent. A recent article in the Australian Financial Review stated that businesses were shelving their investment plans and that figures on capital spending fell by 3.5 per cent in the first three months of this year as a direct response to what is occurring in Asia.

The current account deficit is of particular concern. The Treasurer has played down the prospect of a recession because of the Asian economic crisis. The figures show that we are in a period of slower growth because of the Asian crisis, even though the Treasurer said only a few short months ago that the impact of the Asian crisis on us would be scarcely measurable. He said that the Australian economy was fireproofed. The current account deficit is expanding. The budget papers forecast the deficit to average 5.25 per cent of GDP over 1998-99. This is a current account deficit of around $31 billion, which equals $1,722 for each and every Australian. This is almost double the level of 1996-97, and this is after the Treasurer and the government have repeatedly assured us that the Australian economy has been effectively fireproofed or insulated against the Asian crisis.

The two main concerns with the current account deficit are that: firstly, the forecast is below that of the Reserve Bank, which forecast a rate of between 5½ per cent and six per cent, and below most private sector forecasts; and, secondly, the government's forecast is based on a presumed improvement in Asia during the financial year, which conflicts with most other expectations. This comes from a government which promised before its election that the first thing it would do would be to deal with the current account deficit. We all remember well the debt truck travelling around the streets of Australia during the 1996 election. One can only say that if Labor repeats the dose at the next election, we will have to get a road train to write the figures on after what the government has done to this economy over the past 2½ years.

The current account deficit is running at a dangerously high figure which will lead to a further increase in foreign debt. The ACCI-Westpac report also highlighted that export deliveries were down again, and the expectation is that there will be further falls in the September quarter. Capacity utilisation has fallen sharply and labour shedding is expected to resume in the September quarter. Ordinary Australians—the battlers, as they are referred to—will suffer wholesale as a result of the way this government has managed the Australian economy.

Rural and regional Australians are perhaps the biggest victims of the policies of the Howard government. Simon Crean, the shadow minister for industry and regional development, while speaking on a matter of public importance in the House on 23 June, said:

One of Labor's mistakes in government was to talk about the big picture and simply assume that regions would understand how they fitted in. It was Canberra imposing on the regions, not empowering them. But we have listened and we have learnt. The big picture is still important, but we have to construct it from the ground up, encouraging each region to develop its piece of the mosaic.

The Howard government should have learnt those lessons, but it has not. Throughout the course of its government, it has continued to attack rural and regional Australians. The government has slashed the regional employment development organisations, abolished the infrastructure fund, and frozen infrastructure bonds.

The Howard government has cut services to the bush. It has withdrawn the avenues to job opportunities that existed through labour market programs such as skillshare and LEAP. Job assistance has finished, unless you can afford to pay for it. The government has sliced funding to regional universities, closed regional CES, Medicare and tax offices, and watched as bank branches vanished from regional towns. It has destroyed vital job opportunities.

Australia Post is currently under threat. On top of that, we must now fight against the sell-off of the remaining two-thirds of Telstra. We must fight against continual job shedding in rural and regional Australia. Once again, rural and regional Australians will be let down and left behind. They do not want any part of the sale of Telstra. They want an efficient, effective communications carrier which provides the same services to people in rural and regional Australia as Australians living in the major capital cities enjoy as a right. Labor has been decent enough to announce that, if Telstra is sold, there will be no equivocation on our part and we will not support the sale. An ongoing and fixed proportion of the Telstra dividend will be paid into a fund. Part of that fund will be used for regional development and nation building. This is some comfort for rural and regional Australians.

There is an important connection between industry policy and regional development. The Howard government does not care about that connection—or it does not understand it. This government stood by while BHP announced the closure of its state operations in Newcastle. It stood by while Amcor announced the planned closure of the pulp mill in Burnie, and it did nothing. What sort of public policy creates a situation whereby woodchips from Australian forests sit on the wharves at Burnie awaiting export while they are bypassed on the way in by wood pulp bought from overseas as the feed stock for the Burnie pulp mill? That is a nonsense policy. It demonstrates a clear lack of understanding of what is needed in terms of driving Australian industry into the global economy of the 21st century.

The ALP is committed to developing an industry plan for the forest products industry. That policy will complement the regional forests agreements process. What is the point of securing an ecologically sustainable way of utilising our resource if we are not prepared to value add it? This government has allowed that to occur in the reverse. This lack of action on the industry policy front has not only hit Newcastle and Burnie but threatens places like the Shoalhaven, Maryborough, Whyalla and Port Hedland.

The government's decisions on the book and ship bounties threatened regional centres in Tasmania, Maryborough and Fremantle until Labor led the campaign for their restoration—just as we led the campaign to support the automotive and textile industries. In all these cases we argued that the regional impact was too severe to justify the government's decisions.

The member for Hotham outlined that, if Labor wins office at the next election, we would as a matter of urgency call in the parties in the steel industry and in the pulp and paper industries. We would develop, in partnership, appropriate growth strategies for those industries based on new investment, innovation and the growth coming from net export, and based on a commitment to job opportunities not just for Australians in the capital cities but also for those living in rural and regional Australia.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to join this debate on the appropriation bills. I have spread around me quite a deal of paper, and when I read some of it, I am as confused now as I was when we undertook the estimates procedures. The reason for this is that, within the Department of Social Security alone, we have had three corrigenda given to us for one table. This was a department that started off by handing down their budget statement and several days later we received a large stack of corrigenda, which I then placed in my book. I could not get the figures to add up. I still cannot get the figures to add up. When we have to receive three corrigenda for one table—and it just happens to be the table that is the summary of outlays for the portfolio, so it is probably one of the most important tables in the whole of the PBS—one really has to wonder.

speech.para: I think some of the confusion comes about because it is not clear, when you look at the Department of Social Security figures, what is Department of Social Security expenditure and what is Centrelink expenditure. It has been extremely hard through all of this estimates process to ascertain precisely what is Centrelink expenditure. How much are they charging a number of the departments for the services they are providing?

We do know from the Department of Social Security PBS—well, we think we know some of it—because they have given us a breakdown, but when we have gone and checked with the corresponding PBSs for the other departments, it is not clear just what has been expended. We also find no mention in the Department of Social Security PBS of the work and the pilot that was conducted by Centrelink for the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

It is these sorts of difficulties that make accounting for this expenditure of government money, of taxpayers' money, extremely complicated. I would be critical of the Department of Finance and Administration because I thought that it was the role of that department—an important role—to ensure that the information in these tables was correct. It is the Department of Finance and Administration, surely, that has responsibility in the long run for ensuring that tables add up. When we have had mistakes with that, when we have had transposition errors and when we have had to go back and add in whole new sections relating to Centrelink, one has to say this is not good enough. As I said, it is not clear from the tables that we have been given where and what that expenditure was used for.

We had an interesting situation recently where there were a number of problems for recipients of benefits from Centrelink. In answer to some questions I asked last week in relation to failures with the computers in the Newstart common platform, the minister said that it is a new information system and:
It is also correct to say that it is a very significant improvement on the systems we inherited from the previous government.

Of course, some of the systems they now have in operation have had to undergo considerable change because it is this government that is into the issue of outsourcing the IT services. It is this government that has moved into the agency field as well. The minister said that the previous system was not year-2000 compliant and that the previous government let the computer technology run down. If that is the case, I wonder why, in previous estimates hearings, when I have asked questions of the department about their computer systems and how the upgrades were going, we have heard comments such as the one on 24 September 1996, from the then secretary to the department, Mr Blunn that:

The network replacement I think has been an outstanding success. We brought it in in very short time and well within cost. It is up and running, and running increasingly effectively. There are some teething problems, as there always are. But, basically, it is running very effectively.

Why, if it was running very effectively in September of 1996, is the minister saying that it is our fault now? We also had a question about some of the delays that took place in the mainframe replacement and we got an answer, again in September 1996, from Mr Humphreys. I asked him why we were having an 11th hour rush. Mr Humphreys said:

It is, to some extent at least, tied up with the proposals to actually review the whole of government environment and options to outsource. We need to actually look at any potential to upgrade our equipment within the context of possible outsourcing. That is what has been going on with those coordinating agencies.

So it is not fair or appropriate for the minister to blame the previous government for what she calls computer problems. The blame has to be laid fairly and squarely at the feet, the door, of this government. The Department of Social Security was saying in September 1996 that they were going to continue with their arrangement for, say, 12 to 18 months, pending a decision about the whole of government. They actually put in that tender specific arrangements for buybacks or lease. It is all in the Hansard of 24 September 1996, on pages 553 and 554, and I recommend it for reading. I asked Mr Blunn a question as to how it was going to fit with the agency work. Mr Blunn said:

Quite well. We are planning that. The IT systems will basically go with the agency. The sort of capacity that we need now will be the sort of capacity they will need then. There will be some interface problems, which we are working on now, with some existing computers that DEET use. There are issues—don't let me say there are not issues—but I think we feel that we are comfortably in charge with those issues.
On page 654 of the Hansard , when questioned in October 1996 about efficiency dividends and how improved IT was going to help this, the minister said:

Just as is happening in the teleservice centre, for instance, new and evolving technology is actually making it easier for us to become more efficient without having to use masses of extra staff. There are changes in the IT area which, I think, will help the agency to become more efficient.

That was from the minister herself. This is the same minister who last week or the week before was very scathing of the question I asked and made, I thought, some very rude comments about the previous government in an AAP article on 22 June. The minister is quoted as having said:
The new system had to be introduced because the old system is outdated and not Year 2000 compliant, meaning that it could have been thrown into chaos by the so-called millenium bug.

When questioned on this 12 or 18 months ago in estimates again, why did we have answers from the department that work was being done to overcome this problem and that, within plenty of time, it would be in a position to actually conduct trials prior to 2000?

It does not make sense. This government obviously has a huge problem with its computers that it cannot blame on anybody else. When you look at the expenditure on computers within the Department of Social Security this year, you can see very clearly that quite a deal of additional expenditure has gone into the computing system. Of course, when you have so many corrigenda to tables it gets a bit hard to actually find the right ones, but I think it is well worth noting that in the 1997-98 budget—last year's budget for the current year—DSS said that they were going to expend $18.987 million on computing services to be purchased from Centrelink. There was an additional appropriation sought to take it up to $48.462 million, and my recollection is that they actually expended more than that. The question was asked, of course, as to why this money had to be expended. The answer was that it was all to do with the new equipment that was having to be bought, purchased or leased for Centrelink.

Why this sudden reversal and why this over-expenditure if two years ago we were being told everything was on track and that there were no problems? What have this particular government and this particular minister been responsible for in trying to get their computers working? It is not fair and it is not appropriate to blame anybody else for the computer debacle that has happened in the last couple of weeks; it is one that this government has brought upon itself.

As I said, the appropriation for the expenditure for Centrelink's computing went from $18.987 million to the revised appropriation of $48.461 million. They actually expect to spend $48.462 million and this coming year's budget will be down to $27.51 million. That is an indication that there are computer problems within this area that are solely and wholly the making of this current government. This government has not been on top of this issue and we have seen—

talk.start.para: —Very political!

—Yes, minister, it is very political because this is the budget. I would not have raised this issue if the minister had not come in here and said that it was the previous government that was responsible, when in fact it was not the previous government. We were told two years ago that everything was on track and on track properly. But that obviously is not the case from the things that we have seen falling over in these very recent times. For that, the government should be asked to answer more questions and to look more carefully at what it is doing and precisely what service is being provided, because it is not being provided in the way that people would like it to be provided.

speech.para: I think it is incumbent upon this department to have, within these statements, some way of accounting for what is Social Security expenditure and what is Centrelink expenditure. It is very difficult, when you have one agency mixed up through about half a dozen portfolios, to try to ascertain and question in some logical form the workings and the administration of those particular agencies. That is what estimates and budgets are all about. The process is about undertaking the very careful scrutiny of government expenditure—of taxpayers' expenditure. Is it any wonder that people get frustrated, upset and angry when they see that the expenditure of their money cannot be scrutinised adequately, and that the scrutiny that should have been undertaken was not able to be undertaken?

I suggest that people should read the report of the committee that was tabled here because it was a unanimous report expressing concerns. The department had to come back 48 hours later with a revised set of tables so that we could at least get some understanding of what is going on in that department.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Alston representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Is the minister aware of recent statements by former P&C Stevedores staff that they have been betrayed by the company, the Farmers Federation and the Howard government? Is he further aware of a statement by a former Defence Force officer and dumped PCS worker, Mr Scott Daly, that `the waterfront episode proves that Australian workplace agreements do not protect workers—unions do'?

question.para: Is he aware that another PCS worker, Mr Derek Crerar, said, `My advice to everyone out there is to join a union, because the AWA is not worth the paper it is written on'? Are these not the same workers who were the spearhead of the Howard government push to reform industrial relations using confrontation, guards and dogs? Is it not the case that job security in this country can be brought about only through proper industrial negotiation and award protection for workers?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —It is really a great shame that Senator Sherry is out there perpetuating Labor's retreat to the past. They were very much in favour of enterprise bargaining when they were in government but, once again, in opposition they go back to the future—
—These are your workers; you sold them out.
—I do not know whether it is Scott Daly or not, but there was some bloke who went to PCS for a week and then baled out. Was that him?
—No!
—No, all right. You will get a few disaffected people no doubt wanting to run the union line.
—These are your mates.

—They are not our mates. Overwhelmingly, the people who wanted to go and work for PCS were those who wanted a breath of fresh air. They did not want to be hamstrung by all this `Never get out of first gear stuff' that you got through the MUA.

answer.para: Senator George Campbell interjecting—

talk.start.para: —George, you know as well as I do that they could not spell `productivity' in the MUA. It was a criminal offence to talk about how to lift your game. It was all about `Protect your mates. Do as little as possible. Get as much as possible.', and of course the end result is—
—You used them up and sold them out.
—I do not know if you read Glenn Milne this morning, but it looks pretty interesting to me. What it suggests is that once again these hypocrites opposite, Labor in government—
—Order! Senator Alston, would you withdraw the use of that word, please?
—`Opposite'?
—No.
—Yes, I withdraw, Madam President. Labor in government was interested in waterfront reform—indeed, workplace reform. In other words—

Don't give me that nonsense. Do you think the MUA were going to stand there and listen to someone say that somehow they will stand aside because someone else wants them to? Of course, they would not. You know the language the MUA talk. They were only susceptible to action that would have ensured that the rights of others were protected. This is gross hypocrisy on the part of the fully paid up members of the ACTU over there. Senator Sherry has been in the union movement for so long that he has forgotten what the real world looked like. The thing I found utterly extraordinary was when Senator Lundy got up and said that she did not know much about how the public sector worked because she was from the private sector—in other words, these people in the union movement somehow think they have an understanding of the private sector. They have no understanding at all, because what drives these things in the real world is productivity and performance, the very opposite—

—I was a member of the BLF. Were you? Were you ever in the BLF? Of course you were not. We did a bit of work in those days. We were out there at 7 o' clock in the morning. The only reason I got a job was that, when they said, `No ticket, no start', I hung around and when half of them did not come back at lunchtime from the pub they took me on. It was the only way I was able to break that union monopoly. There I was being paid for doing an honest day's work.

answer.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, you get the advice that you ask for. Even the Labor Party knows that. The advice he got back was standing down the MUA work force, cancellation of MUA awards and agreements—
—How do you know? What is your source?
—Senator Ray, there is an appropriate time to pursue this.

—Deregistration of the MUA, action under boycott laws and action under the Crimes Act for interference in international trade. The ALP in government, through its subcommittee of cabinet, set up to crush the MUA in the middle of the ANL dispute, was receiving this advice from its advisers. Who was on this cabinet subcommittee? Interestingly, it included Mr Beazley, now the Leader of the Opposition. He was apparently a party to seeking this advice. What did he say? answer.para: Mr Beazley was asked today what was his knowledge of these events. We know the then government was addressing the very options that it now condemns this government for. What we do know about the Labor Party is its record on the waterfront, that is, a five-day, nation wide strike in September 1994 which cost $55 million—Senator Cook might well say that in those circumstances we were justified in looking at every option—leaving Australia with an average crane rate of about 17 containers per hour when the world's best practice was close to 30 containers an hour, spending $420 million paying out waterside workers which gave Australia an improvement of only five additional containers an hour and caving in to union pressure over the sale of the ANL.

This government took a tough line on the waterfront because we believed reform was necessary to provide the increased productivity that was in the interests of all Australians. We have now been able to do that and that will be of benefit particularly to exporters but to all Australians through increased jobs now that there is a better chance of having a competitive waterfront and gaining those benefits in terms of our overall economic challenge. We took the hard decisions; all the opposition did was preach hypocrisy. (Time expired)

The Howard government has done this and the community will benefit through a more productive waterfront. It has not been easy, but governments are not elected to take easy decisions.

—My question is directed to Senator Ellison, representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Does the minister recall that in 1996 the Prime Minister stated at the National Press Club, `I will be a very disappointed man if I haven't made very serious inroads into youth unemployment in this country because I would like to see our performance in that area as being a mark of what we have been able to do as a government'? —Madam President, it is really pretty cheeky indeed of the opposition to raise this point because, under their government, youth unemployment was over 32 per cent. What we are talking about here is a figure around the region of 27 per cent.

answer.para: Madam President, it is a fact that youth unemployment is always too high, and it is something that this government is addressing. We are addressing this through training programs and through increased numbers of apprenticeships. The fact is that we have contracted with providers in the next 19 months to bring about 200,000 new apprentices.

We are looking at the 70 per cent of young people who do not go on to university—unlike your government, Senator Mackay. We are looking at these people in terms of increased vocational education at school. We have kept and enhanced the JPET program for homeless youth, for youth with problems. We are increasing training opportunities for young people. We have increased the bridge from school to work for the jobs pathway program.

This is an area where the opposition just cannot talk. They have a disgraceful record in relation to youth unemployment. Unemployment rose to heights of over 11 per cent, full stop. Who was the minister then? It was then the current Leader of the Opposition. The Leader of the Opposition presided over those figures.

They have an absolute cheek to raise the question of youth unemployment when we look at what this government is doing. This government is committed to fighting youth unemployment. We will fight to reduce those levels, and we will get them down to levels much lower than that opposition over there ever did when they were in government.

talk.start.para: —Is this abysmal performance the reason why this government is planning to spend a minimum of $4.5 million on a youth advertising campaign, on top of its current dishonest and misleading $3.8 million youth allowance campaign, to try to cover up the government's abject failure to meet its commitments to young Australians?

That is where you will get the real benefit for young Australians. We have underpinned growth for new apprenticeships, through funding to the states and also through direct funding from the Commonwealth, with over $550 million. That is what we are doing for the young people of Australia.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
