—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. You will have noticed One Nation's new policy of banning immigrants who do not pass an English test. Would it not be simpler to block or export people who are not clear on the name of our country and who think it is an eight letter word, minus the `l', pronounced `Austraya'?

—I thank Senator Brown for his question. There are a number of points to make with respect to the senator's question. I do not want to underestimate the importance of getting the balance in the immigration program correct. The coalition has significantly strengthened the English language requirements for migrants since we came to office. We have done that in a number of ways. Firstly, the proportion of applicants who are subject to English language requirements has been increased, because this government shifted the immigration program from a situation of two to one, family reunion and skilled migrants respectively, to one of roughly 50 per cent family reunion and 50 per cent skilled migrants. It is in that area where there are English requirements.

answer.para: The level of English has also been significantly increased so that most successful applicants must have vocational level English rather than just a functional level of English. Some 85 per cent of all occupations for which independent and skilled Australian linked migrants enter Australia now require vocational English. Previously, it was only about 20 per cent. The government has also introduced points for English language ability to be taken into account in the skilled Australian linked category, formerly the concessional family category. That was originally disallowed by non-government senators in 1996 but was finally passed in 1997. From November 1997, vocational English has been a standard requirement of the employer nomination.

The second point I would like to make is that the substance of these changes has ensured that the migrants arriving in the skilled migration categories stand much better chances of obtaining employment in Australia and therefore contributing to the economy. In addition, the adult dependence of all skilled stream migrants who do not speak functional level English are required to pay for the English language tuition before they are granted a visa. Senator Brown, that is to indicate the importance of English; let us not pretend it does not have a role to play in helping migrants secure a job.

But to require every single migrant to have English language ability is simply not practical. Are we really going to expect refugees fleeing persecution to pass an English test before we let them in? Can we really expect an Australian to wait while their life's partner passes an English test before they can live together in Australia? Can we really expect a dependent child of an Australian to pass an English language test before they live with their Australian parents in Australia? The answer to those questions is no.

Those three groups of migrants make up almost 50 per cent of the total migrant and humanitarian intake. Around 12,000 will be visaed in 1997-98 on refugee or humanitarian grounds. About 25,000 spouses and fiances and more than 2,000 dependent children will come in.

Ms Hanson has gone further than that and suggested that New Zealand's English requirements—I regard our friends in New Zealand as friends, but it is somewhat insulting to suggest that they have a better arrangement than we do—are more extensive than Australia's. As with so many other things she says, she is simply wrong in that respect. Like Australia, New Zealand applies English language requirements to general skills and business investor categories. There is no English language requirement in New Zealand for family and humanitarian arrangements.

In conclusion, the coalition parties have a strong and very proud record on immigration. It was this side of politics that got rid of the White Australia policy, and it was this side of politics that first welcomed Indo-Chinese refugees into Australia after the Vietnam War—in stark contrast to the people now in opposition who did not want that to proceed.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The Greens are also totally opposed to this despicable potential policy. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, and I refer to the proposed uranium mine at Jabiluka. I also refer to the strong statements by Minister Parer and Minister Hill when they said that 77 conditions would be imposed on the mine, in accordance with the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Both ministers referred to those conditions as `strict and stringent'. Does the minister stand by his claim that those conditions are strict and stringent? Can the minister inform the Senate if any of those conditions is legally enforceable? If they are not legally enforceable, how can he use the term `strict and stringent'? If they are legally enforceable, under which sections of the legislation are they legally enforceable? What will the minister do about breaking condition 56 that there must be a cultural heritage management plan in place before the operations commence?

—I would like to thank Senator Alison for that question. Let me just put this on record, and I think I tried to do it last time but ran out of time because it was in answer to a supplementary question: this was a claim made in the media and also made by other people in recent times with regard to section 56. The journalist himself, as I mentioned previously, failed to find out the actual conditions imposed on ERA by me.

answer.para: In considering the proposed Jabiluka uranium mine, Senator Hill provided over 70 recommendations to me as the action minister under the administrative procedures of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. I am required to give all such directions and do all such things as can be done to ensure that Senator Hill's recommendations are taken into account.

After considering his recommendations, I took them into account in placing requirements on ERA. In response to Senator Hill's recommendation that a cultural heritage management plan be developed—and that is what you are referring to—I imposed the following condition:
In complying with Jabiluka environmental requirements 36 and 32, ERA must take into account the intent of recommendation 56.

I adopted this approach, in response to Senator Hill's recommendation, so as to integrate them into the existing legal framework set out by the Jabiluka environmental requirements provided for under the Northern Territory mining lease under which the project will operate.

The environmental requirements already require the carrying out of an archaeological survey of each area to be affected by construction work before construction work commences in that area. ERA has provided a six-monthly progress report detailing how it is proceeding with the additional studies which I required the company to progress. The six-monthly report advised that ERA had appointed an environmental officer as required by environmental requirement No. 3. The report also states that a detailed survey was carried out by ground inspection of the mine site in March 1998 and that no prehistoric archaeological sites and no isolated stone artefacts were identified in the survey area. In addition, no historically significant archaeological materials of Aboriginal or European heritage were identified.

The six-monthly report also notes that the principal traditional owner has refused to participate in any consultation with ERA over aspects of the environmental and social monitoring report. This is consistent with the media release issued by the NLC in May this year. It states that the NLC is not in a position to negotiate on behalf of the traditional owners of Jabiluka for the mine because they are opposed to the mine. ERA has advised that all strategies and commitments required for a cultural heritage management plan are in place, but that there is no formal plan yet because the traditional owners have said they will not meet with ERA to discuss any aspect of Jabiluka while ERA continues to go ahead with the project.

The six-monthly report was also used by the Northern Territory in giving approval for the commencement of the construction of the mine portal in decline. In making this decision, the Northern Territory minister sought the advice of the Supervising Scientist. The mine site technical committee, which includes the Northern Land Council, has regularly met. On 19 May, it considered actions and work in progress in relation to the requirements I placed on the company, including the issue of surveys of archaeological and heritage sites.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer to the question. However, an archaeological survey is not a management plan. As I understand it, the Northern Land Council, which he says is not in a position to negotiate, has not even been approached by ERA. I am happy to look into that further. I ask the question again: are those so-called strict and stringent conditions enforceable? I understand that they are not. What steps will the minister take to make sure that they are? Again, when will the minister ask the company to cease operations in accordance with those conditions which have not been met and in accordance with the World Heritage Bureau's request that they do so?

—I have made it clear that the archaeological studies have been done. The only thing is that there has been no formal plan yet. The only reason why there is no formal plan is that the traditional owners have said they will not meet with ERA to discuss it. I repeat that, even though Senator Allison does not believe the NLC has been approached, I issued a media release in May this year, which I quoted to her in answer to the previous question.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—On 22 June, Senator O'Brien asked me a question relating to matters that arose out of the Economics Legislation Committee on 3 June 1998. With the concurrence of the Senate, I seek to incorporate the answer into Hansard .

answer.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

On 22 June 1998 Senator O'Brien asked me a question in four parts about proceedings during the estimates hearing of the Economics Legislation Committee on 3 June 1998, and I undertook to consider the question and report back to the Senate.

The fact that a minister indicates that the government will not respond to questions does not make the questions out of order. It is for ministers to take responsibility for any government refusal to answer questions.

Senator O'Brien also asked what action I would take to ensure that chairs of Senate committees act in a fair and impartial way. There is no evidence that Senator Ferguson was partial in his rulings on this occasion and I believe the Senate is well served by those of its number who chair committees.

Senator O'Brien asked what action I would take to ensure that Hansard is a true and accurate record of the proceedings of Senate committees and is not censored by a committee chair as he challenged happened on this occasion. I will draw the terms of this answer to the attention to the Chairs of legislation committees.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, after the taking note of answers I will be seeking leave to make a statement in relation to that answer.
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), to questions without notice asked by Senators Forshaw, Patterson and Lees today, relating to Telstra.

I think it is very clear from the responses of Senator Alston that this government has absolutely no concern for the ordinary working people of this country. His flippant approach to questions relating to the future of Telstra under privatisation demonstrate that this government does not really care about the future impact of a privatised Telstra.

I turn to what is currently happening under this minister's stewardship of Telstra. Whilst 33 per cent of Telstra has been sold, it is still under majority government ownership. For many years under previous governments, when it was 100 per cent owned by the people of Australia, Telstra provided, through its White Pages, a service known as the Easy Guide. It was an easy guide to emergency phone numbers that persons in need of assistance could quickly find at the front of the White Pages.

As I indicated in my question, these services provide information for people who may be in need of, for instance, emergency accommodation or assistance for drug and alcohol addiction. This page, which has always been inserted into the White Pages, includes information on, for instance, agencies providing family support and agencies and private sector organisations providing services for people with disabilities. Very importantly, it provides emergency telephone numbers for persons who may have been the victim of rape or sexual assault or, similarly, people who may be in need of urgent psychiatric assistance. Just about everybody in this country is familiar with the telephone due to the universal service provided by Telstra over many years. It has always been understood that if you needed emergency information you could go to the front of the White Pages and it would be set out under the various categories.

In estimates a couple of weeks ago, it emerged that the information that is provided by the Department of Health and Family Services in the front of the White Pages would discontinue. When questioned as to why that was the case, the officers representing the department indicated that Telstra was reviewing its charges and that it was going to increase the charge to provide this information—information which is inserted as a community service—by somewhere between $400,000 and $600,000 per annum, so the price would go up to about $800,000 per annum. The department decided that that was too much to pay.

What a disgrace that that is happening with a government owned instrumentality such as Telstra, whose responsibility is to provide telephone services for people, organisations and companies in Australia, and which also has the responsibility of ensuring that the people in this country can find the telephone numbers they need. What is the point of having a telephone service if nobody can find a number when they need it? That is why the White Pages are there, and the emergency numbers are up the front so that they are easier for people to find.

However, the Department of Health and Family Services is going to discontinue this invaluable service, a service that is there for people in desperate need. When Senator Alston was asked what he was going to do about it—whether he was going to talk to Telstra and say, `This is not on. You can't just treble or quadruple your charges in the case of providing such essential community information'—he made jokes about the disabled and people who may be hard of hearing. That was the response.

talk.start.para: —He did not.
—The Hansard will demonstrate it, Senator Patterson. You can have a look at it later. That is what we got. The minister is a joke and the government is a joke. (Time expired)

—I rise to speak to the motion to take note of the various answers on Telstra which Senator Alston gave in question time today. Senator Forshaw has spoken very eloquently about the way in which this government has allowed Telstra to callously remove from the White Pages appropriate community information for people so that they know where to ring to get advice and assistance in a time of need.

speech.para: This minister will always roll over in favour of Telstra's management. The minister might ring up Frank Blount from time to time and say, `Tut, tut, Frank, can't we do better?' but he will not put the pressure on, even though he still represents two-thirds of the ownership of Telstra—the Australian people. On a number of occasions, this minister has refused to take direct action and use the parliamentary power under the existing act to direct the board of Telstra.

For example, the dreadful COT cases came to the notice of the Senate estimates committees. Through arbitration, one of the COT case people won a big payment to pay for legal expenses, but Telstra refused to pay. When we asked the minister why he did not get onto Telstra and tell it to carry out the instruction to pay, in accordance with the arbitrator, he said that he had written a letter but Telstra had chosen to ignore it.

Telstra's management chooses to make this minister its doormat, just as the Prime Minister has made this minister his personal doormat on communications and ABC policy. Today, we saw another extraordinary performance when the minister answered a question from Senator Lees about the release today by the Australian Communications Authority of its performance monitoring bulletin for the quarter ended March 1998.

Before the bulletin was released in late mid-morning, the minister was forced to put out his own statement anticipating the bad news in the report. He said that he was disappoint ed that Telstra had not been able to improve its service performance, particularly for people in rural Australia and that, therefore, he was going to increase the fines for non-performance from $11.65 to $40 a day. He did not point out in his press release the shocking decline in Telstra's performance.

If rural members of the Liberal Party or, more importantly, members of the National Party in this parliament are going to defend the people they are supposed to represent, they should read this report. On page 4 it says that Telstra's performance for the provision of new services on or before an agreed committed date in country areas continued to decline, falling another two percentage points to 64 per cent during this quarter. It says that, compared with the corresponding March 1997 quarter, this was a decrease of 17 percentage points.

The report then reports what Telstra said in various states. That shows that, in the full 12 months since Telstra was privatised, since the bill was carried in this parliament, country connections in Australia declined by 17 per cent. As far as I am aware, this is the biggest decline in country services in the history of Telstra, Telecom or the PMG. We know that in parts it might have come off a low base, but since the government has allowed one-third privatisation, it has gone down 17 per cent. This was a shocker for the minister.

What did the minister say today? He said that he was going to increase a few fines. Will he take action to direct Telstra to improve the service? Will he ask what it is doing with investment? Not a word. This minister is useless, hopeless and helpless when it comes to dealing with Telstra. It is no wonder, when people in the bush see the decline in this service and that neither this government nor the minister does anything about it, that One Nation's support is getting away in the bush and cutting up support for the coalition.

That sort of service is why over two-thirds of Australians oppose any further privatisation of Telstra. That is why the people in the bush are in open revolt against this government on the privatisation of Telstra. That is why this minister's day has gone. That is why this minister should go immediately—he cannot direct Telstra to improve services to people in rural Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I found that performance rather amazing, given the fact that Senator Schacht must have been the most appalling and most abysmal minister for communications that this country has ever seen. We have seen the absolutely appalling introduction of various telecommunications policies—

—I raise a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. For the sake of accuracy in the record, unfortunately have never been the minister for communications. I certainly will be the minister after the next election.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I meant the shadow minister for communications. He is an appalling shadow minister who really dabbles around. It is very obvious. He has been abysmal in his performance as shadow minister. The bureaucrats sit on the other side during estimates and scoff at his questions and believe he does not pay attention to detail. He is hopeless. He has got up here and gone on about Minister Alston, who is actually doing things and reforming the system. When we look at the Telstra service levels of performance for the March quarter—
—Service in the bush has gone down.
—Order! Come to order, Senator Schacht!

—Madam Deputy President, I sat here in absolute silence listening to Senator Schacht—it wasn't worth listening to, but I sat here in silence—in deference to him and in deference to the Senate, but he chooses to interject on me all time. He did not say what he wanted to say when he was on his feet, and now he wants to have a second go at it. It is appalling. It is just like him: he cannot actually get his words out the first time round, cannot get his argument over the first time round, and he then wants to interject on me when I am speaking.

speech.para: Telstra has a national obligation to maintain its service at the levels which Australians expect and deserve. Its quality of service levels have been unacceptable for a number of years, particularly in regional Australia for many years under Labor.

talk.start.para: —It's got worse under you lot.
—Order, Senator Schacht!

—For example, it is true that only 64 per cent of faults nationally were cleared within one working day of notification in the December 1997 quarter and 63 per cent in the March 1998 quarter, but it is also true that this fault clearance level had exceeded 75 per cent in only two quarters in the four years to December 1997.

speech.para: Thank heavens Senator Schacht is leaving the chamber—now I will be able to go on without being uninterrupted. We continually expressed concern about service levels when we were in opposition, but Labor did nothing for 13 years. That is why we promised before the 1996 election the introduction of the customer service guarantee scheme, requiring carriers to compensate customers for not meeting standards on phone installations, repairs and appointments. We delivered on that promise, and the scheme took effect from 1 January 1998. Labor had 13 years to do something about it and did absolutely nothing. Now Senator Schacht comes in here as the weak shadow minister for communications, bleating about the fact that we have done nothing about Telstra's performance.

The Labor Party did nothing in government, and in opposition all they can do is carp. I will repeat what the coalition has done: we promised before the 1996 election to introduce a customer service guarantee, which requires carriers to compensate consumers for not meeting standards on phone installations, repairs and appointments. It took effect on 1 January 1998. However, it seems from today's figures that Telstra is taking too long to lift its game. That is why we are sending them an unmistakable message with today's announcement that per day fines under the customer service guarantee would rise to $40 if Telstra has not connected or repaired a service by five working days after the time period specified under the customer service guarantee.

Labor's feigned interest in rural telecommunications issues stands in stark contrast to its appalling lack of any concrete action to address these issues for over a decade. It has a total lack of credibility on rural telecommunications, which is demonstrated by its failure to require Telstra to speed up the digitalisation of its telephone exchanges, thereby giving rural phone users access to advanced phone services, as the coalition has done; its failure to require Telstra to provide rural Australia with high speed digital data capacity through the rollout of ISDN capability, as the coalition has done; its failure to examine the need to upgrade the definition of the standard telephone service to take into account new technologies, as the coalition is doing; its failure to provide any substantial financial support to meet the specific telecommunications needs of rural Australia, as the coalition has done; and its opposition to the coalition's $250 million regional telecommunications infrastructure fund, which is providing much needed support for rural communities, including the establishment of points of presence, enabling local call access to the Internet. This opposition has no reason to be complacent and no reason to crow. It has done nothing about the issue of Telstra and what Telstra is doing.
I have given just part of the record of what the coalition is doing to actually bring Telstra into line and deliver services to consumers, in particular those in rural and regional Australia.

talk.start.para: —I call Senator McGauran.
—Order! Senator McGauran has the call. We had two on your side and now there will be two on this side.
—That is correct, Senator Sherry—you had two in a row.
—But you didn't get up.

—That is the usual procedure. The government welcomes this debate on Telstra, which precedes the debate on the legislation which is due to take place at the end of this week. That is the whole point of this debate and the attack by the opposition: to attempt to discredit the government's privatisation program for Telstra and the enabling legislation to come before the parliament. It is nothing more than that. It is a trumped up attack on the government's privatisation program.

speech.para: Senator Schacht has not seen through this debate. As Senator Patterson has said, you would think he would have seen through this debate to the end. He has not done so. He did not ask one question at question time, nor did he lead the taking note of answers. So that is a measure of the shadow minister's effort in this debate.

The point is that the government's two-thirds sale of Telstra, which is to come before the parliament, is an honest, up-front attempt to seek a mandate from the people, as was our one-third sale of Telstra. Before the 1996 election the government sought from the people a mandate for the one-third sale of Telstra.

talk.start.para: —Did you agree with that?

—Yes, I did. The government sought, and got, that mandate, as we will do with this legislation and prior to the next election. The legislation will not be enacted until after the next election. That is in stark contrast to any privatisation program that the previous government had—for example, the Commonwealth Bank. They went to the elections saying they would not privatise the Commonwealth Bank beyond one-third. Straight after the election, they did. In fact, as I recall, the then Treasurer, Mr Willis, even put it in writing to the existing shareholders of the Commonwealth Bank that they would not be privatising any more of the Commonwealth Bank, but they did.

speech.para: That is the difference between our privatisation program and the previous government's record—we seek the mandate of the people and we get the mandate of the people. So to say, as Senator Schacht has said, that 70 per cent of the people in rural and regional Vict oria do not support the privatisation is spurious. There is no such figure at all—not that I can remember the last time that Senator Schacht ventured out into the rural and regional areas; they do not seem to be his domain at all. When I venture out into the rural and regional areas, I do not get that sort of feedback at all in regard to Telstra. When it is explained to country people that one of the main benefits of the government's two-thirds privatisation of Telstra will be the reduction of the government's $100 million debt—that the proceeds of the sale, estimated to be some $40 billion, will be taken off the government's debt, and the benefits of that reduction—

talk.start.para: —They will turn to One Nation.

—They will not, Senator. They accept that that is a very good reason. The question is often asked, `What underwritings are you giving in regard to the USOs to rural and regional areas?' We have stated time and time again that the rural and regional areas will not be left behind with regard to privatisation. The situation is quite the opposite. Telstra will continue to be governed by the universal service obligation in law. This universal service obligation ensures that all Australians, in particular the rural and regional areas, must have access to the standard telephone service and access to pay phones regardless of where they live in Australia. This is put into law and this is enforced. One of the passions of the minister is that the USOs are strengthened and put into law with the two-thirds sale of Telstra. They are the sorts of guarantees and assurances that we are giving, and they are the guarantees and assurances that are being accepted in the rural and regional areas.

—I am glad that Senator McGauran finally got to his feet to participate in this debate on behalf of the National Party. He is a bit like telecommunications equipment in the country—he is always late. Senator Patterson referred to the opposition `carping' about the decline in quality of telecommunications in the bush—in regional and rural areas. I want to refer to another senator in this place and to his criticisms—carpings, if you like. They are those of Senator Ron Boswell, and I will refer to them in a few moments.

speech.para: The opposition highlighted today, with the questions to the minister, Senator Alston, the continuing decline in telecommunications services in rural and regional Australia. And of course what was highlighted was Senator Alston's failure to give adequate answers as to why this decline in services has not just continued but has actually accelerated. The Australian Communications Authority has released performance figures for the March 1998 quarter which state:

Country customers received the lowest level of service for new service connection, with performance declining from 82 per cent in the December 1996 quarter to a low of 64 per cent in the March 1998 quarter.
We have had a significant decline in new service connection—

talk.start.para: —And they've been brought to account.

—But they have not been brought to account. These figures are for the March 1998 quarter. That is very recent, Senator McGauran. The interesting thing is that since the one-third privatisation of Telstra, when we were assured—not just by the minister but by the Prime Minister and the National Party—that quality service would increase in the bush but it has gone backwards.

speech.para: What did Senator Boswell—your leader, Senator McGauran—say about this on 30 March this year? Presumably he is one of the senators that Senator Patterson was referring to as `carping' in his criticism. After they had voted to sell off one-third of Telstra, Senator Boswell, Leader of the National Party in the Senate, said on the Channel 10 morning news:

We will want guarantees written into the legislation. We will want the community service obligation firmly written in the legislation. We will want enough people out in the bush to service the telecommunications system.

The point is that this was on 30 March 1998. If the CSO—the community service obligation—was written in, and if there are supposed to be guarantees about staffing levels, where was Senator Boswell representing the National Party?

On 30 March 1998, after the legislation had gone through, after you voted for it and after you said you were protecting the bush, Senator Boswell is still complaining. He wants the guarantees in legislation. Obviously the guarantees have not been effective, and that is certainly highlighted by the report from the Australian Communications Authority.

We had a very good example today of the continuing decline in the quality of service since the one-third privatisation of Telstra. The question was posed by my colleague Senator Forshaw. The emergency numbers currently cost $200,000 and the price is to increase to approximately $800,000. These are life and death community service organisation notices that are supposed to appear. All Senator Alston could do was to enunciate a hands-off policy—a do-nothing policy. When Labor, quite rightly, is demanding an improvement in the quality of service under a one-third privatised Telstra, all he can do is say that we are undermining shareholder confidence with our demands, that basically we would be running the company, and that governments should not be giving these sorts of directives. What Senator Alston is outlining is a hands-off policy—a do-nothing policy.

The only way to guarantee a proper effective service, particularly in rural and regional Australia, and the only way to guarantee service quality, to stop the acceleration in staff reductions, and to protect rural and regional Australia is to ensure that the remaining two-thirds of Telstra remain in public hands. A fully privatised Telstra will obviously seek to maximise profit—you cannot blame them for that. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to use the few minutes that are available to me not to unnecessarily denigrate the other side, which has an appalling record in telecommunications, but to assure the Australian public that what my government proposes to do is the only and correct course to take with respect to the two-thirds balance of Telstra. The government intends to give the people of Australia the opportunity to decide—as it should do in a democracy—whether or not the balance should be sold and thereby have a fully privatised Telstra. The government has said that, if it is possible to get that legislation through this Senate in spite of the spoilers on the other side—

speech.para: Senator Sherry interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Sherry, you are not the person to speak on that, and I would ask that you—

—I raise a point of order, Madam Deputy President. I was just rightly drawing the attention of the chamber to Senator McGauran's level of discomfort at the word `rationalism' in Senator Lightfoot's contribution in this debate about the sale of Telstra.
—There is no point of order.
—I ask Senator Lightfoot to address the chair. I ask Senator Carr to remain silent.
—As I said, the only rational thing to do is to sell the balance of Telstra, but not without the permission of the people of Australia. A government cannot be fairer than that.
—What about the bush?

—When I said `not without the people of Australia', Senator Sherry, in his appalling ignorance, said, `What about the people in the bush?', as if the people in the bush do not matter in Australia. That has been the problem with the Labor Party. They do not understand that people in the bush are part of Australia. This side of the house understands that. This side of the house understands that people in the bush are an integral part of Australia.

speech.para: Now let me get on with my contribution. What we intend to do is leave the legislation on the table, as it were, and if and when the government of today wins the next election then we would take that as the imprimatur of the people across Australia to enact the legislation to fully privatise Telstra. That is the only way to go. The Labor Party did not say anything about that—it did not say any thing about privatising the Commonwealth Bank, the icon of the Labor Party. Australia was going to fall apart if we privatised the Commonwealth Bank. Well, Australia did not fragment, fall apart and fall into the Pacific or the Indian oceans; Australia carried on and Australia did a very good job with the Commonwealth Bank. The Commonwealth Bank today is functioning as it did before. It is offering some of the best rates to Australian people. And it is one of the better things that the Labor Party did. Even if they lied to the Australian people about the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank, it was one of the better things that the Labor Party did in their subterfuge.

Today we need to have Telstra privatised completely. You cannot expect international telecommunications companies with the redoubtable expertise that international companies have to come in and compete in Australia—which we invite them to do—if Telstra is government owned. There are very few countries in the world, if any—yes, Red China is one and Nigeria is another one—that still have central control of telecommunications. Cuba still has full control of telecommunications. I think there is something like neo-communism on the other side that gives them this compulsion to control telecommunications, because they believe, like in the old bolshevik days, that if you control telecommunications you control the people. That revolution was a long time ago, I have to tell the opposition. Rationality has to prevail. But it is not only economic and commercial rationality that is going to prevail. What this government is going to do is give the people of Australia, in this wonderful democracy, the opportunity to say, `Yes, we are going to accept the full privatisation of Telstra.' or `No, we are not.' Nothing can be fairer than that. There is nothing covert, nothing about l-a-w, law—we are going to write it into law—nothing of that nature. There is nothing here like saying `We are not going to privatise the Commonwealth Bank', and then, as soon as you get the reins of power in your dirty little sticky fingers, the first thing you do is privatise it. (Time expired)

—by leave—At the conclusion of question time, in the statement by Madam President relating to a question I asked on Monday, 22 June regarding the asking of questions at estimates and the intervention of the Chairman of the Economics Legislation Committee to ensure that part of a question did not appear in Hansard , let me say, having received the answer, that I think further information should be placed on the record. Firstly, it should be noted that the question that was asked clearly was not out of order and that there was no basis for the chairman purporting to rule it out of order. That is a matter which is clearly stated in the President's statement today. That was my view at the time.

speech.para: The Senate ought to be made aware that what occurred at that time was something which I had not previously experienced. When it was noted that part of the question had been omitted from the Hansard, Mr Logue of my office contacted the Chief Hansard Reporter to inquire as to how that had occurred and, in a letter dated 5 June addressed to me, received the following answer:

Mr Logue of your office has discussed with me the Hansard report of the proceedings of the Senate Economics Estimates committee of 3 June 1998. Specifically, he has referred to the omission at page E216 of certain material which you read in the course of the hearing.

When the committee suspended for the dinner break that day, a copy of your quotation was supplied to the Hansard officer maintaining the log of committee proceedings. However, the Chairman of the committee, Senator A Ferguson, advised the Hansard officer that `only those words that Senator O'Brien asked before he was called to order should appear in Hansard'.

In the preparation of the transcript, the advice from the Chairman was adhered to. I understand that this advice was discussed by the Chairman with the secretary of the committee before it was given to Hansard.
Bernie Harris
Chief Hansard Reporter

It is important to note in relation to this matter that, but for the intervention of the chairman, it is clear that the Hansard would have reflected the full content of the question and, indeed, the question was not out of order. What occurred was clearly an intervention by the chairman to ensure that that part of the question was not in the Hansard . My understanding of proceedings in Senate committees is that it is open to any member of the committee to seek that matters which are referred to in proceedings not be included in the Hansard but that that matter would be drawn to the attention of the committee. As a matter of courtesy, I would have expected that Senator Ferguson would have drawn to my attention, when I returned to the committee following the dinner break, that he had advised, asked or directed Hansard to do that which he had advised, sought or directed them to do, but that was not the case. As I indicated, the first time I noted that the matters had not been recorded in Hansard was when looking at the Hansard the following day.

A great many things occur in this place and in committees where comments made may be the subject of a call to order, but Hansard continues to record them. One would only have to go to answers to questions by Senator Alston who persistently ignores the calls of the chair to cease his answer and continues his answer. I suggest that his answers are recorded in the Hansard. It seems to me that it was quite an unusual step for Senator Ferguson to take to exclude from Hansard that part of the proceedings, the question clearly being in order, the document in fact being affirmed the following day as legitimate and one which I was seeking to ask questions about in order to affirm its veracity or otherwise. All of this occurred in the context of proceedings where there was a persistent refusal to answer questions by the minister, allegedly on the basis that matters were sub judice, notwithstanding advice from the clerk that the question of refusing to answer questions on the basis of sub judice had no basis at all in terms of the standing orders or the practices of the Senate. An advice received by Senator Mackay in that regard had been tabled before the committee.

Madam Deputy President, this matter arose in relation to the waterfront issue. Questions arose about the conspiracy that this government, with others, had been involved in to take action to remove the Maritime Union from the waterfront. A great number of questions were asked on that matter at the estimates—and in this place, and on notice—none of which has received proper answers. In my view the questions have been addressed without proper regard to the standing orders of this place.

It is interesting to note that the proceedings affected by the advice of Senator Ferguson were extensively reported on ABC radio and elsewhere the following day. So, to the extent that this was an attempt to censor the matter, it failed, but it is an important matter nevertheless. It is, I believe, a matter which the Senate and committees should have regard to in relation to how committees proceed and how the chairs of committees behave when dealing with questions, the validity of questions and, certainly, in relation to any directions or requests that might be made of Hansard.

May I suggest that, if it is a view that a matter is not properly in the Hansard, then a chair of a committee, before intervening, ought to have at least a conversation with the senator affected so that the matter is not required to be dealt with in the way that I have had to deal with this matter—that is, by raising it with the President.

Let me say that I cannot find anything in the standing orders which justifies the actions of the Chairman of the committee, Senator Ferguson, in this matter. The President in her answer has not drawn my attention to any parts of Odgers which might relate to that matter. If there are such references I would be very pleased to receive them so I can study them and fully understand the basis for the actions that have been taken.

Let me say that I regard this as an extremely unfortunate incident. I hope that all chairs of committees and all senators will take notice of what has occurred so that these events do not occur again.

talk.start.para: —by leave—Madam Deputy President, I first became aware of the detail of Senator O'Brien's question to the President this morning. May I suggest that, if Senator O'Brien had shown some of the courtesies that many of his more experienced colleagues choose to use—that is, had he discussed any grievances with the chairman and the committee, perhaps, before running off to the President or the Clerk for advice—then some of the matters that he has raised might have been easily explained without him having to go to such great lengths.

speech.para: I want to correct a couple of things that Senator O'Brien said. He spoke about my intervening in the Hansard process and that I directed Hansard to remove material. Can I say to Senator O'Brien, through you Madam Deputy President, that nothing could be further from the truth. I, in fact, was approached by Hansard when the hearings broke for dinner and asked for some advice as to whether or not some things that were said by Senator O'Brien should be included in Hansard because I had called him to order and, on their tape, there were two voices running concurrently.

I did not direct anybody to do anything without seeking advice. I sought the advice of the committee secretary. His advice was that, after Senator O'Brien had been called to order, where two voices were running concurrently, in fact that was the time—although I cannot remember his exact advice word for word—when words that were spoken by Senator O'Brien should not be recorded as it followed the time that he was called to order.

Otherwise, Madam Deputy President, you could have a situation where—perhaps in this place—you were trying to stop somebody from reading a document that was possibly sub judice and, even if you stood on your feet and that person kept on talking, in fact it could go into Hansard. I was advised by the clerk this morning that, if that is the case, Hansard reporters in this chamber simply turn off the microphone so that it cannot be recorded.

talk.start.para: —That is not right.
—I am only relating to you the advice that I received this morning, that in fact that is what happens.

speech.para: Also, Senator O'Brien said that it was on my initiative that I intervened with Hansard. In fact that is not the case; Hansard came and spoke to me at the start of the dinner break to see what should happen. I sought advice, and that advice I then passed on to Hansard. It was not on my initiative at all; it was initiated by Hansard. Had Senator O'Brien given me the opportunity, even the next day or later on that evening, I certainly could have helped him with that part of his question.

In his question to the President, Senator O'Brien also asked, `What action will you take to ensure that chairs of Senate committees act in a fair and impartial way?' Madam Deputy President, I have been chair of a committee for only some four years, but Senator O'Brien is the first senator on that side to imply—and that is what he does in his question—that I have not acted in a fair and impartial manner.

While that is his prerogative and he is quite at liberty to accuse me of acting in an unfair and partial manner, I can only say that, in the running of most estimates committees, perhaps there could be more interaction between senators, both prior to and after hearings. Senator O'Brien has been in this place for only a couple of years or so and may not have learned from his predecessors how Senate processes normally operate, or he may not have been advised how they normally operate. In fact, a lot of the things that he raised could have been dealt with.

The other thing you asked the President was: `What action will you take to ensure that Hansard is a true and accurate record of the proceedings of Senate committees and is not censored by a committee chair?' In fact, a chairman has no power to censor anything that Hansard does, and I certainly did not attempt to. As I said, I was initially approached by Hansard. It was only after that approach that I sought advice and relayed that advice back to the person in Hansard—I cannot even remember who the Hansard reporter was. That is the way that I treated it. I did so in what I thought was the fairest manner possible.

In regard to Senator O'Brien's suggestion that I was in some way abusing standing orders, I consider that, during the process that day and during some of the other estimates hearings that we had for three days, senators on the other side were abusing standing orders consistently when they were being called to order and were continuing on. If Senator O'Brien wants to accuse me as chairman of being in some breach of standing orders, I would suggest that he read the Hansard carefully and look at how often he and some of his colleagues were in breach of standing orders.

As a matter of fact, the opposition do not even understand standing orders. I was surprised when Senator Cooney entered into the fray during that estimates hearing after Senator O'Brien asked to table a document, was refused leave and so at that point Senator O'Brien moved that my ruling be disagreed to—when, in fact, I was not making a ruling at all. I was just refusing leave which is in accordance with standing orders. Anybody can refuse leave. We then had Senator Cooney trying to say that they were moving dissent on a ruling when I had not even made a ruling. All I had done was refuse leave to table a document, and he somehow suggested that was in some way a breach of standing orders.

Through you, Madam Deputy President, I make these suggestions to Senator O'Brien in order to prevent this sort of thing occurring in the future: if you had spoken directly to me as the chairman—or any other chairman—or if you had raised it with the committee at the time or at an appropriate time after the dinner break, then you could have saved yourself a lot of trouble. I know that during this estimates most of your dinner break was spent preparing more questions. One of the problems that arises under the way you conduct the questioning is that, if the questions are prepared by somebody else and you do not get the right answer, you do not know where to start asking the next question. I think that is what caused some of the problems that happened on that day when repetition became the order of the day. We spent some three hours on one or two particular small points, which you sought to make some political capital out of but failed miserably.

In conclusion, the premise on which Senator O'Brien's question to the President was based was wrong in that I did not direct Hansard to do anything. Hansard approached me. I sought advice before I said anything to them at all, and then only passed on to them the advice that was given to me.

This petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are still the only Australians, sent overseas on active service, whose service has not been recognised in three important areas:

Members of the Army and R.A.A.F. who served during the same period in Malaya had their service fully recognised 24 hours after arriving in Malaya.
