The complicity or, at the very least, the lack of will on the part of the federal government to encourage public examination and discussion on this threat to the Australian people is very similar to their reluctance to debate that other attack on Australians also sponsored by Labor and the coalition—
you are both to blame—
the MAI.

Both of these treaties will take power and choice from the majority of our own people and place that power and freedom of choice firmly in the hands of foreigners and self-seeking minorities. Both of these treaties diminish Australian sovereignty and in the case of the so-called rights of the indigenous people could ultimately result in the disintegration of our nation.

So you see that it is the identification of an enemy. And it is important that you identify somebody who can be the focus of the hatred, the fears, and the prejudice of people who are feeling very insecure.

After identifying the enemy, the next stage is to vilify the enemy. Vilification of the enemy is to project the enemy as a foreign invader, owing no loyalty to the rest of the people, suspected of outside allegiance to forces trying to infiltrate, subvert and overthrow us. The tactic was used by a number of right-wing groups in the 1980s to try to prohibit or limit Asian immigration to Australia. Of course, again, vilification of the enemy is one of the things that Ms Hanson did in her speech. I can read a few extracts:

. . . the time has come to concentrate on the dangerously and inappropriately named rights of the indigenous people. When signed, this treaty will become a permanent fixture of division. It will divide us not racially but geographically. This treaty is a treacherous sell-out of the Australian people—
et cetera. Then she goes on to describe what she calls the activists of the Aboriginal industry and says:

. . . those who help peddle their lies have preyed on the collective conscience of other Australians. We have seen the distortion and blame-filled confrontation of the so-called stolen generations, sorry day, sorry books, and the list goes on.

In other words, vilifying the enemy is to take the one that you have identified and to heap upon them as much approbation as possible so that in the minds of people the enemy is not only identified but also vilified. That begins to take away from the enemy the ability to present themselves as belonging in any sense. By separating out the enemy and by vilification it is very clear that this again focuses people's attention, their insecurity and their fears.

The next stage in the process of creating an enemy is to brutalise the enemy. Let me give you a description of what I mean by `brutalisation'. It is a step in the process in which it is possible to create a climate in which groups which have been identified and vilified can be physically abused and mistreated, and the abuse is overlooked. That is exactly the reporting that we are getting from Asian communities in Australia and from the Aboriginal people. The incidence of racial attacks, both verbal and physical, on these groups of people has escalated significantly in the last two years.

So the third stage in the creation of an enemy is to brutalise that enemy. It becomes possible within that context to treat those groups of people who have been identified as though they are non-human and therefore it is possible to abuse and brutalise them without much fear of retaliation. This is what Ms Hanson did in her speech. I do not have time to go through and pull out all of the quotes but, for instance, she says:
The fact is that native title is just a precursor to the establishment of a taxpayer funded Aboriginal state.

I have to remind you that in the 1980s in my state of Queensland there was a gentleman by the name of Geoff McDonald who wrote a book called Red Over Black . His theory was that Aboriginal land rights was about creating sovereign Aboriginal states in the north of Australia. Then when they were created, the Aboriginal people would invite the communists to invade, they would set up bases in the states and they would be able to invade the rest of Australia. One would think that is a pretty preposterous idea, but parliamentary members of the National Party took Geoff McDonald around Queensland to public rallies in order to push this ridiculous assertion. That is what happens when you identify, vilify and brutalise somebody as the enemy.

The fourth and last stage in this whole process of creating an enemy is, having done all of that, you can then eliminate the enemy because at this point it has been established in the mind of the public that the enemy is non-human or subhuman, a foreigner, vermin, subversive, likely to introduce infectious disease, et cetera. At that stage, the elimina tion of the enemy is not doing something against human beings but almost a public service.

It is this kind of creation of the enemy which is very prevalent and very obvious in the speech of One Nation's leader, Ms Hanson. That is why I think it is possible to establish not just in a pejorative sense that One Nation is a fascist party, but in a technical and literally correct sense to say that this indeed is a revival of fascism of the 1920s and 1930s. This is particularly so in relation to the creation by the One Nation party of an enemy within the Australian body politic and to see the possibility of the elimination of that enemy. That is in fact their policy in terms of removing from the appropriation bills any appropriation to those Aboriginal organisations which are essential to the health of the indigenous people of this country.

talk.start.para: —I wish to make some observations with respect to the 1998-99 federal budget. In particular, I want to touch upon how this budget and the preceding two budgets are ripping the heart out of Tasmania and the Tasmanian people. We have a health and unemployment crisis in Tasmania that this federal government must take most of the blame for creating.

speech.para: It is becoming a little tiresome when Senator Abetz comes into the Senate casting the blame at the feet of the Hawke and Keating governments for all the current problems being experienced in Tasmania. There is a sense when Senator Abetz speaks out not just of arrogance but of self-righteousness in that the coalition still deserve to be absolved from any blame for the mess and pain that Tasmania and many parts of the mainland are experiencing.

Why should the coalition government be absolved from blame for an unemployment rate of 14 per cent in the electorate in which I live—Braddon—according to the latest small area labour market data? I asked that question when in March 1996 the rate was 11.5 per cent. In March 1996, the electorate of Braddon, in comparison with the other 147 electorates, was ranked 29th equal worst electorate in the country for unemployment. Should the coalition not take some of the blame for that electorate now being ranked 14th worst for unemployment in Australia?

It will not be long before the electorate of Braddon hits the top 10 in the hit parade on unemployment rates. That will please all those long-term jobless and all those young unemployed people who are struggling to come to terms with the Job Network now representing the brave new world of employment. Let us not forget that there are now over 30,000 more people who have joined the ranks of the long-term unemployed than when the Treasurer announced the start of his long economic trek in 1996.

In that period the proportion of people unemployed for in excess of a year has climbed from one in four to one in three. It goes without saying that there has been a mass migration of people out of Braddon. With the mill in Burnie closing there will be many more, because 280 people will lose their jobs in October. They are moving not just out of Braddon but out of Tasmania. With many other people giving up hope of finding work, the 14 per cent is a lot worse than it looks. I believe that for the young unemployed the rate is as high as 40 per cent.

What torture the unemployed have had to experience on this so-called first leg of the trek they have had to travel. It has been a long forced march where along the way many battling Australians have been crippled and left behind. How can the Treasurer, Mr Costello, claim that the burdens were shared and the benefits will be shared? The problem is that those that suffered the burdens will be the same families and battlers that will receive little of the so-called benefits. They have been left behind on this forced march. There has never been an inkling that this Howard government may return to pick them up and give them a helping hand.

This government stopped caring about people when the first budget was announced. It has only got increasingly worse since that first budget. The battlers will not share in the benefits. Under a GST they will always be denied that chance of recovery from what has been a difficult journey for them. The battlers do not have the benefit of a family trust which delivers to the rich a regime where minimal tax is levied. What a Labor government can promise the battlers is that they will not have to pay a GST on any of their goods or services. Labor is committed to creating jobs in regions of high unemployment and we will never leave the battlers behind.

I now turn to the area of health. Why should the coalition be absolved from blame for the health crisis being faced in Tasmania? Again, Senator Abetz freed himself and his government from any blame for the health crisis in Tasmania. He did not blame the Labor Party in total this time but condemned his state Liberal colleagues and said they were misrepresenting the true picture of the contributions made by the Commonwealth. But why should the federal government be absolved from blame for axing a public dental health scheme that now has Tasmanians waiting in excess of three years for a set of dentures or some preventative dental work? Far from being blameless, why did the government, in this budget, not put some of the $2.7 billion surplus into dental care and reduce the waiting times for Tasmanians and the rest of the nation?

The same goes for the denial of the Howard government for the provision of free hearing aids. Why should the federal government be absolved from blame for forcing many of our aged to pay more for prescription drugs, including blood pressure and heart condition medicines? An increasing number of people are now compelled to travel from my area on the north-west coast of Tasmania to Launceston for care and treatment unavailable on the coast. Should the government be absolved from assisting in creating that problem? I think not.

Why should the federal government be absolved from ripping $30 million off the bottom line in base funding in health care grants for the 1998-99 year to Tasmania? Why should they be absolved from the fact that the Medicare negotiations have turned out to be such a frustrating and belittling experience for the Tasmanian government? In the electorate in which I live there are two major hospitals primarily serving the people of Braddon. They are under enormous pressure with their waiting lists. Some of this public hospital crisis must lie squarely at the feet of the Howard government.

Let us not forget that in the coalition's first two budgets $3.6 billion was cut from the health sector. It is a shame that in this latest budget there has been a failure to resolve massive haemorrhaging of the health system. But it is to be expected, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), and no doubt many of his colleagues, want to preside over the demise of Medicare and bulk-billing. Again, they will probably want to be absolved from those measures.

There was no message of opportunity or avenue being opened up for most Tasmanians in this budget. I have indicated that the unemployed, the sick, families and the elderly are suffering, but there are many others that have been hit hard by this government. I hope we can bring an end to this suffering and go back on the track we have been forced to follow and give them a helping hand.

talk.start.para: —In this debate on the appropriation bills I want to look at the adequacy of the funding for the ABC. The transition to digital funding is inevitable and one of the most important broadcasting advances that the whole world will undertake, and that includes Australia.

speech.para: The ABC, along with the commercial free to air networks, provided the government with estimates of the costs that digital conversion would involve. The latest estimation of the three commercial metropolitan networks was that the cost to the three of them together would be in the vicinity of $740 million over the initial years after commencement—say, about five years.

The ABC on the other hand—a national network which broadcasts in all metropolitan and regional centres—provided the government with a funding submission for an amount of less than $180 million. This amount was broken into two phases. The first phase was for the preparation of new television studios, outside broadcast vans and transmission. For radio, it includes digital broadcast consoles, digital audio workstations, and the conversion of studios to digital. This phase one of digital conversion is for a five-year period. The total cost to the ABC of phase one is estimated to be about $108 million.

So how much has the government allocated in this budget? A pathetic $20 million over the next five-year period. Yet the government has determined its whole digital policy on the burden the conversion costs will create for the commercial broadcasters. It is patently obvious that the government is allocating far, far less than the ABC will need for digital conversion, even after an independent inquiry found that the ABC's estimates were accurate and even though the government appears to accept that the metropolitan commercial networks will need to spend about $250 million each. Let me just reiterate those figures: the ABC requires $108 million for its phase one digital conversion, and the government has allocated it $20 million. The metropolitan commercial networks believe they will require about $250 million each for their conversion to digital, and the government appears to unreservedly accept that estimate.

Why is the government so obviously vastly underfunding the ABC's conversion to digital? Why did the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) feel it was necessary to have a consultant review the ABC's funding submission? Why has the government slashed funding to the ABC generally? Why has the government closed down Radio Australia's state-of-the-art Darwin transmitter—the voice of Australia inside Asia—just when everyone else is increasing their short-wave presence in the region and just when we most need to speak as a nation to the ordinary people of Asia?

The only explanation I can see is that many members of the cabinet have an unhealthy obsession with the ABC, because they believe the ABC to be biased. In effect, the budget allocation tells the ABC to behave. Can these allegations of bias against the ABC be substantiated? Quite simply, no. In fact, 79 per cent of all respondents to a poll commissioned by the national broadcaster earlier this year, and reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 11 May, stated that the ABC did a great job and was balanced and even-handed in politics. Ninety-five per cent stated that the ABC did a good job in providing reliable and accurate news and current affairs programs. How unfortunate for that 95 per cent of Australians that the five per cent of Australians who do not agree must include the cabinet members who have total control over the ABC's funding and eventually, of course, over the ABC's very existence.

The ABC board requires reports on accuracy, impartiality and objectivity within the network. The board has only required these reports of the organisation since the coalition came into office. The board obviously identified very quickly what was underwriting the government's agenda. But the government simply has not been able to prove their ridiculous notion.

Issues included in the current report—the three months to March 1998—covered some of the most important issues our nation has debated: native title, the Constitutional Convention, the Indonesian currency crisis and the Iraqi crisis. Since then, of course, we have had coverage of the MUA dock dispute. The government's allegations of bias against the ABC have been unrelenting ever since, including the minister's letter of complaint to the ABC's managing director, when Senator Alston knows very well that the chair of the ABC board is the person to whom he should direct his concerns.

The minister has claimed that the ABC is not being scrupulous enough in ensuring their coverage of the waterfront dispute was impartial and accurate. However, Senator Alston said in an interview on Media Watch on 8 June that his main concern is that:

. . . there are proper mechanisms in place to monitor—not just have nice words in the guidelines—but to ensure that the ABC recognises the importance of having the community at large see it as acting in a fair and impartial manner.

The minister is also concerned that `the ABC places too much emphasis on social issues than economic issues, when clearly that is not what the vast majority of the Australian population wants.' Some of the minister's colleagues have also made this claim in recent Senate committee hearings.

But what about the ABC's charter? The ABC will pursue issues which are not considered mainstream, not because it is a recalcitrant broadcaster but because its charter requires the ABC to transmit programs that contribute to a sense of national identity and inform, entertain and reflect the cultural diversity of the Australian population—and thank goodness they do. We live in a society; we do not live in an economy.

Australians are deeply interested in social issues, in cultural issues, in the arts, in politics and in the economy. What a boring place it would be if we heard only about economic issues and sport—although sometimes I do get that feeling! And if the ABC did not offer these alternative program streams, then who would do it?

The present ABC ratings are higher than they have ever been. People are choosing to watch the ABC in greater numbers than ever before. The ABC evening news service is rating second in the four main news services. Does this mean the viewing public is not able to discern what comprises a good program and that only the government understands that?

The ABC's relationship with the government of the day has never been, nor should it be, a natural alliance. The ABC is accountable to the parliament, not to the government. Where a government has a direct interest in the outcome of a particular issue, its assessment of the ABC's performance will, of course, be clouded. This becomes truly dangerous though when the government links its criticism to ABC funding. And what is dangerous for the government is when the community recognises what the government is doing. The public values an independent ABC. Australians want the government to leave the ABC alone and to restore its funding base. But the minister remains steadfast in his allegations of bias against the ABC. These culminated recently in the minister attacking the adequacy of the ABC complaints handling procedures and issuing a media statement outlining a five-point plan for the ABC based on the BBC's procedures.

But the ABC has an independent Complaints Review Panel which provides a review of complaints about bias, accuracy and impartiality. This is not the same body as the National Advisory Council, which Senator Tierney mistakenly confused with the Complaints Review Panel, when he said it was part of an ABC club and that five of its six members were journalists and therefore not representative of Australians. To set the record straight, the NAC is an independent statutory authority established under the ABC act. It makes its own decisions about the ABC, and it provides independent advice to the board on matters relating to broadcasting generally. It is comprised of 12 members who are selected from all walks of life after open advertising.

It appears to the vast majority of Australians that the ABC broadcasts with the public interest in mind and that it remains fair to all sides of the debate, which is difficult in a politically charged atmosphere. There will always be allegations of bias made against the ABC and, more often than not, from the government—any government. But alleging bias against professional journalists who operate within the context of editorial and ethical guidelines is not very impressive.

It is time for the government to stop this ridiculous, tedious and dangerous campaign to destroy the ABC. It is time to fully restore ABC funding, to re-establish Australia's short-wave voice into Asia, and to provide the ABC with the funding it requires for digital conversion in order that it can keep broadcasting to the high standard that we expect into the next century.

talk.start.para: —Perhaps the best way to describe the budget is as a missed opportunity. The government had an opportunity and a chance to address some of the major issues confronting Australian society and the economy today. It could have done that through a range of innovative policies and the continued funding of proven successes. Instead, and perhaps somewhat unsurprisingly, the government took the same old route of slashing funding and withdrawing entitlements from the sectors of society that need them most. I would like to concentrate this evening on a couple of issues where the government has been quick to recognise the problem but very slow to provide answers, if any.

speech.para: Foremost among these is the issue of unemployment, and youth unemployment in particular. For a government which likes to claim fiscal expertise and responsibility, the coalition has been stubbornly asserting that simply relying on high growth is one way of delivering jobs for the 8.1 per cent of Australians who are still out of work. This is in the face of a financial crisis in the Asian region and the potentially looming recession and depression in Japan. The simple equation that high growth will necessarily result in lower unemployment or an increase in job creation is an extraordinary assertion when you take into account some of the other economic and social factors.

The Committee for the Economic Development of Australia stated in May this year that growth would not be as high as predicted and certainly not high enough to deliver the jobs that were promised by the government. It was certainly not high enough to deliver the growth rate predicted in budget papers, let alone when the government first came to office almost three years ago. It identified investment in human capital and research and development as the means by which employment can be created. This is certainly a position that has been long advocated by the Democrats. You have to have a measure of intervention. Governments have to be positive and active in the focus of job creation.

Only today it was revealed by the Australian Bureau of Statistics that 3,000 businesses across Australia have indicated that they plan to cut jobs by almost one per cent in the coming year due precisely to the Asian economic crisis. Furthermore, a survey of 11 academic economists has indicated that it is very likely that Australia will be in recession for the next two years. The government clearly cannot try to perpetuate this assertion that economic growth will deliver jobs, because this is simply not going to happen.

The other answer we get from government and Treasury officials when we are talking about the answer to unacceptably high levels of unemployment has been the idea of the introduction of a competitive employment services market to replace the former government run service, a universal service that was publicly funded and accessible to all. But we have now seen the absolute privatisation of employment services in this country and their replacement with a competitive market privatised employment service.

It is interesting to note that the government has also treated this reform as an opportunity for cost cutting and for profit making with its service provider, Employment National, directed to make a profit at the expense of job creation. Approximately $37 million was saved through a tender process which favoured cheaper bids. This comes on top of the $1.8 million that has already been cut from the provision of employment services. With a large number of smaller providers trying to remain open—almost struggling to remain open—and hampered by the unviable contracts they have been awarded, and a lack of promised referrals from Centrelink to provide them with the necessary capital, the Democrats urge this government to bring about a review, a review that was promised for the end of the year. The least the government could do is refund the $37 million which the Treasurer, Peter Costello, boasted of saving.

The government must undertake some positive action to create jobs. It cannot simply rely on the rhetoric of growth increasing. This budget has attacked some of those very measures and strategies that were responsible for assisting job creation such as labour market programs. But this, like other budgets, has seen cuts to these very areas. Of course, we have seen cuts to the processes by which unemployed people are assisted in looking for work.

One of the remaining few schemes, the highly successful new enterprise incentive scheme, also suffered a budget cut. Even a scheme that was demonstrated to have positive and high results in terms of placement suffered a budget cut of $8 million, leaving it with $25.5 million to carry out its work of encouraging unemployed young people in particular, but unemployed people generally, to start their own businesses.

Despite its rhetoric that unemployment `is the single most important issue facing Australians', this government evidently feels that it is not important enough for it to take positive action—some form of interventionist action, some kind of action to create jobs. It is relying instead on unlikely growth. This government is not prepared to monitor and fix some of the flaws that beset its new employment assistance service. It is a $1.66 billion Job Network gamble.

This government continues to slash funding to job creation and to labour market programs. Sadly, one area where the government has been willing to take some action has been in attacking young people. I note for the record that tomorrow is the last day that young Australians will have an effective national representative peak body. The government's decision to axe the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition, known as AYPAC, makes Australia one of the unique nations amongst OECD nations in terms of our lack of a national, universal and peak representative body for young people.

This is a mean-spirited, ideologically motivated decision, designed to silence the voice of young people the day before—and I suggest that this timing is rather coincidental—the introduction of the new income support system for young Australians, the common youth allowance. This is a policy that will see many thousands of young people cut off from benefits and dependent upon their families for support. By the government's own admission, this is going to happen. We are going to see tens of thousands of young people either losing support completely or having their benefits reduced.

There are a number of nasty measures in this legislation. Before the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, insists on correcting the record by saying that there are some positive elements, people have acknowledged that the streamlining of income support payments is a positive thing. Ensuring that people do not have to run between one department and the next, say, the Department of Social Security for unemployment benefits or the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs for Austudy, if you are a student, that you do not have to have that kind of administrative bungle or inflexibility, is a good thing.

However, it seems that the government has taken the lowest common denominator approach. So you have an income threshold that kicks in—just over $23,000 per annum; you have ages of independence which are absolutely concocted. They are a sham—to think you do not qualify for the independent rate until the age of 25 if you are a student or 21 if you are young and unemployed. Do not forget that this common youth allowance also allows for 16- and 17-year-olds who are not in employment, education and training to be completely knocked off benefits. We are still yet to hear from the government how those families, potentially struggling families, are going to look after their essentially old teenagers or young adults. But then again the government does not consider people independent or of adult status until 25 in some cases.

So there are regressive, indeed nasty, parts of this legislation and this policy framework that the government has yet to explain or rationalise in a way that makes sense to ordinary Australians. It makes sense if you are a hard-nosed government that wants to meet a budget bottom line and does not factor in social, intellectual and other deficits that can impact on a society as equally as can a budget deficit.

The government is actually going to spend $3.8 million on an advertising campaign to convince young people that the common youth allowance is advantageous to them and $4.5 million on telling young people about youth issues. Yet it will only put $225,000 into giving young people any access to policy development. This is only twice a year, so a select few—roughly 50 people—will meet for a round table experience with Minister Kemp.

talk.start.para: —What's second prize?
—I can see people lining up for that one! You will have to get in line, Senator Conroy! So entitlements have been cut for over 45,000 people.

speech.para: I point out, as an aside, that even some of those advertisements have met with some challenge and wrath from members of the community. I know that there is one advertisement running now, which members of parliament may have seen, in which the actor playing the role of father, referring to his younger daughter, talks about the common youth allowance and all the great benefits it is going to bring young people. He then makes an offside comment that he will not necessarily be there and who is she going to have there to give her a `kick up the bum'. I think members might have heard that some members of the public have complained about the overtones of that ad. They cannot even get their ads right. If it is going to spend more money on the advertising than it is on young people's representation, the government could at least get it right.

This budget has shown once again that the government has no answers to unemployment, that it prefers scapegoating young people, cutting funding and shutting down services to taking positive action to stimulate jobs growth, job creation and providing assistance to those who need it most.

talk.start.para: —A former Liberal Prime Minister once said, `Life wasn't meant to be easy.' It was not easy for him either in some respects.
—Who said that?

—Good old Mal. But the current Prime Minister, Mr John Howard, has redefined those words into two sets of standards: one for those who are wealthy—they get the `life is meant to be comfortable, relaxed and secure' version—and the other for the unemployed, elderly, sick and those who are trying to get an education. They get the `life is going to be damned difficult and we intend to make sure of that' version. When we look at the most recent budget of this government, we can see exactly what the Prime Minister means.

speech.para: What the Prime Minister does not seem to realise is that people do not get too excited about economic and social pain, especially when that pain is so unnecessary. Over the last three budgets, Australians have been forced to suffer a significant amount of unnecessary pain. If we look at the area of unemployment related programs, the government has slashed $1½ billion from those and $3 billion from education. If we look specifically at employment services, we see that both the unemployed and employers have lost access to independent, easily accessible, free employment services, as were provided in the main by the CES and some private providers.
I would like to draw to the Senate's attention a recent statement of the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, who said:

Employing Australians is the greatest single social challenge of any government, federal or state, in the 1990s. And the decisions we take in every area of political responsibility must have a high priority in the area of employment.

However, since the government has come to power, it has closed down 293 CES offices around the country, including eight in Tasmania. In the electorate of Bass, the electorate where my office is based, on 1 May 1996 there were 63 CES staff working to help the unemployed in the Launceston area alone. There are now only 11 people staffing the new government agency, and it is no wonder that people are finding it so difficult to get a result in terms of finding a job. Moreover, the previous private employment services that we had under the Working Nation programs are now gone as a result of the government's new approach to the provision of such services.

This has created an even worse situation for the unemployed living outside of the metropolitan areas. For example, a young person living at, say, Deloraine, which is some 50 kilometres from Launceston, who requires assistance in training and various other aspects of seeking a job, is left with little hope. This is because, following the introduction of the government's new FLEX 1, 2 and 3 system, Link-Deloraine, which is the only employment service in Deloraine, only has a FLEX 1 contract. Therefore, it has no capacity to provide the services for those young people who require additional assistance. They are left with the situation where they have to travel to Launceston, at best. They have to pay a bus fare for which, as I understand it, they do not get any assistance. It makes a mockery of what this government said about looking after the regions of Aus tralia, particularly those outside the metropolitan areas.

In a recent survey, it was discovered that every one of the 134 job agencies around Australia associated with Jobs Australia reported that they were struggling to make the John Howard Jobs Network operate to help the unemployed. The survey found that referrals are not happening, at least one agency has not had a single referral and agencies are reporting problems with the way data is collected. To quote one respondent to the survey:
The biggest concern is the way everything is tied to Flex 1. Employers still don't know what is going on. Referrals are very slow and Centrelink staff aren't helping.

When we look at some unemployment rates around Tasmania for March 1998 compared with the same period in March 1996, we find that unemployment in Bass in 1996 was 10.3 per cent and it has now risen to 12.7 per cent, Lyons has moved from 11.3 per cent to 12 per cent and Braddon has blown out from 11.5 per cent to 14 per cent. These figures clearly undermine claims by Liberal members and senators that they are delivering to Tasmania.

In regard to the question of delivering to Tasmania, we had a Tasmania package from this Liberal government prior to the last election which said it would do a number of things, but what has happened is that we have got nothing in return, except to say that the shipbuilding bounty—which is very important to one of Tasmania's most significant employers in the state, Incat—is going to be abolished. Has the government taken a further decision on that? No. The Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme has been cut by some $10 million or $11 million. What has that done to assist employment?

The government did deliver one thing, I suppose, and that is in relation to the Bass Strait car equalisation scheme, or the Bass Strait passenger equalisation scheme. It is not really a passenger equalisation scheme because it actually gets paid on cars. The intention of that scheme was to ensure that Tasmania's tourist industry—another very important industry in the state—would see more people coming across Bass Strait to Tasmania, but what has happened? Yes, like any new scheme, there has been an increase in passenger numbers, but the net effect of this will be that all the Bass Strait passenger equalisation scheme is doing is underwriting the bottom line of TT Line. It is not delivering. In fact, passengers per car number have actually declined. It is not delivering so far as our state is concerned.

The outlook for Tasmania and the country as a whole is not getting any better. The government itself has projected a fall in economic growth from 3¾ per cent to three per cent. On top of that, it then projects that somehow unemployment is going to fall to seven per cent by the end of 1998. Unfortunately, those predictions cannot be supported by the facts. Of course, this is from a Prime Minister and Treasurer, in particular, who said that they had fireproofed the Australian economy against the Asian economic crisis. I would suggest that the fireproofing that the Treasurer has put in place is about as good as that which was employed by the Romans in the burning of Rome.

talk.start.para: —This is getting a bit scholastic for you, Murphy.

—I do not want Senator Ferguson trotting off and asking for part of my speech to be expunged from the Hansard on the basis that he thinks I am out of order. I hope, Mr Acting Deputy President, you will not do that.

speech.para: As I said, our Prime Minister and Treasurer said that we were fireproofed against the Asian economy, but the fact is that we are losing huge chunks of our export market in a very important part of our overall export market. This is also despite the value of the dollar being lower, which should actually enhance some of those aspects of our export markets, and it does mean an improvement in some of our commodity prices.

This, as I said, leads to a total decline of exports from the region, and this then leads to local business growth slowing and unemployment continuing to rise at an ever increasing rate. Indeed, in the Financial Review on 17 June, it was reported that:
. . . business confidence has collapsed to its lowest level since 1991, prompting Westpac Banking Corporation to lower its economic growth forecasts for 1998-99 to just 2.25 per cent.

Most professional analysts predicted the same and some of them were saying that growth could fall below two per cent. That does not augur too well for employment growth. I do not need to remind government senators of what they used to say when we were predicting growth figures of around 3¾ per cent. They thought you had to have at least four per cent and in excess of four per cent to actually get some improvement in employment growth.

So what do we have after three Howard-Costello budgets? We have got investment intentions at their weakest levels since 1989-90. We have got the falling dollar—the dollar fell through the roof and almost hit the floor—falling exports, reduced output, declining rates of business investment, rising unemployment, rising home mortgage rates and almost zero business confidence in the government's ability to manage the economy.
As I said earlier, all of the social pain in the main has been inflicted unnecessarily. As my colleague in the other place Gareth Evans rightly pointed out on 26 May:

. . . if Labor had still been in office, if there had been no policy changes since the last Labor budget, we would have been facing a deficit this year of minus $2.7 billion on the government's own figuring. That deficit could . . . have been covered by a modest deficit reduction program of $3 billion worth of cuts taking effect this year.

This has to be taken in the context of the fact that you announced a budget surplus. In effect, the same budget surplus could have been achieved through our policies but with more growth, more jobs and without the social dislocation that has been caused by the government's budgets.

I will turn to health. In my home state, the Liberal state government is still at odds with the federal Liberals, accusing them of cutting health funds to the extent that our hospital system is almost falling apart. I agree with the last part of that claim. Our hospital system is almost falling apart, but we have to accept a bit of argy-bargy from state Liberal governments. In fact, the Tasmanian public have been hit by a double whammy—both the state and federal Liberal governments have cut health funding significantly. Indeed, the Rundle government has reduced state health funding by around $40 million over the last two years, whilst the last three Howard-Costello budgets have taken $1.62 billion out of national health care funding, which includes $800 million from public hospital funding and $400 million from the now non-existent dental health care program.

In terms of the state figuring, it has been claimed by the state government that, in a total sense, the figure for Tasmania of $15 billion has been cut from the budget by the Commonwealth. One specific example of how this translates at a local level is the loss of $3 million in funding for essential free emergency dental care. State funded dental care is no longer available to people in need, since the Prime Minister has axed that program.

Having taken this money out of the public health system, the federal government has re-offered it as private health insurance rebates, the prime objective being to increase the level of private health membership. Of course, when announcing the government's program, the Minister for Health and Family Services, Dr Wooldridge, said that, by the year 2000, 40 per cent of the population would be covered by private health insurance. As we said at the time, exactly the opposite has happened. Since the introduction of the government's rebate system in the 1996-97 budget, instead of increasing private health membership, there has been a further 2.2 per cent drop, leaving 31.1 per cent of the population in private health cover. That is continuing to decline at around 800 people every day.

If that money they offered up as a rebate to private health insurers had been put into the public hospital system, it would have provided an extra 3,000 beds and reduced waiting lists by around 100,000. It is also interesting to note that some of the Liberal premiers—particularly two notable ones in Jeff Kennett and Richard Court—have said that the government's strategy in terms of its rebate system is a dud and a waste of money. They are not the only ones concerned. There are many prominent members of the government who are concerned about the priorities and the spending mix of the government's budget.

For example, the budget allocates $1 billion to the Federation Fund. That is not to say that the money will not be well spent and there are not programs around that are deserving of money from a Federation Fund, but it could well be argued that this money has been taken from budgets of essential community services that so many Australians desperately need like hospital beds, elective surgery, dental care and nursing homes. So one has to wonder at the logic, especially in light of the announced budget surplus.

Another area in which the government has demonstrated its total inability to deliver social policy is aged care. On Wednesday, 1 July 1998, the government plans to move a coalescence of funding, or, in other words, to introduce a national rate of aged care funding for all states. In effect, this simply means more cuts. In Tasmania, the move to coalescence means a further $5 million cut to aged care.

In a letter sent to all Tasmanian MHRs and senators dated 23 June 1998, Huon Eldercare stated that the `effect of coalescence alone will result in reduced funding to this home each year of around $105,000 in real terms'. This will result in either increased fees for nursing home care or decreased services, or both. Therefore, it is not surprising that, in a paid advertisement in the Mercury on 23 June, the organisation Aged Care Tasmania had this to say by way of an open letter to the Tasmanian community:
Reductions to Aged Care funding will be disastrous for Tasmania.
I will read just some aspects of the letter, which states:
Due to a decision made last year by the Federal Government, Tasmanian providers will be asked to do all of the above with a REDUCTION IN MONEY over the next 7 years.
The decision has been made to take money away from Tasmania, over the next 7 years, under the "Coalescence" to national average subsidies program, and give it to other States.

That may well be the case. In summary, we see in this budget the pain of not one extra dollar for public hospitals that was not on the table when the premiers walked out of the Premiers Conference, the pain of not one extra dollar for dental health, despite the continuing blow-out in waiting lists for emergency and preventive dental care, and the impotence of a government which has no new ideas for how to increase levels of private health insurance membership while its own budget papers show that it expects private health insurance membership to continue to fall.

This is all from a government and a Prime Minister who said he was for the battlers. I guess the battlers, as the PM put it, will be entitled to judge him according to the benchmark of whether or not he has honoured the commitments he made before the last election, just as he said they would.
Budget cuts are not the only misery that he intends to hand out. This Prime Minister and government plan to give the battlers a GST. What will a GST do for the average mums and dads?

talk.start.para: —Never, ever.

—That is right; he said, `Never, ever.' But now it is, `We will, we will, we will.' What does it do for the mums and dads that he and the government said should feel secure, comfortable and relaxed? It was their right. The promise prior to the last election was that, in government, the coalition would make Australians feel comfortable, secure and relaxed. The GST will have an effect on everything from arts to transport. What is clear is that Australians will not be better off and that a GST tax system will be far from fair.

speech.para: I wish to make a very important point in the last minute I have available to me. This GST that the government proposes to introduce is not in the interests of Australians, particularly those who buy chips from fish and chip shops, and hopefully not from Pauline Hanson's fish and chip shop. It will not be fair on Australians. The government has said that it is an employment generator. If it is an employment generator, why has it not worked in those countries that have a GST? Why has it not served to generate so much employment for them? If the govern ment is going to stand up and say that it has worked in the US, it had better look, because the US does not have a GST. Australia does not want one. We will do everything possible to ensure that we do not get one after the next election.

talk.start.para: —Senator Murphy raised a very important point about the introduction of a goods and services tax and its relationship with employment levels. One of the more interesting examples of a country that has recently introduced a goods and services tax is Japan. Japan introduced a goods and services tax at a level of three per cent five years ago. It increased that goods and services tax to five per cent in April last year. I do not lay all the blame for the five years of difficult economic times that Japan has had on the introduction of and increase in the goods and services tax, because it would be exaggerating things. However, it certainly has not helped the Japanese economy. Unemployment is going up. It has technically gone into recession. It is a good bad example, unfortunately, of the impact that a goods and services tax can have. As I say, I do not subscribe all of the difficulties Japan has to the goods and services tax. However, it certainly has not helped.

speech.para: I want to touch on three areas tonight. The first is the material provided to the various estimates committees. Second, I want to make some further comments on the goods and services tax, or the never, ever tax, as it is better described. Third, depending on the time, I will make some comments about some potential mining developments in my home state of Tasmania.

We have just been through the estimates hearings, where we examined the budget statements for each portfolio area. I know that Treasury officials are watching this debate. Apparently since the election of this government, they regularly tune in from Treasury and phone the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and offer advice. I know that they are looking in. Of great concern to Labor senators were the significant number of errors in the base documentation provided to the Senate for the conduct of Senate estimate hearings. I do not lay the blame totally at the feet of each departmental portfolio area, though each is certainly partly responsible. We need an explanation from the Department of Finance and Administration, which is responsible for the number of errors that occurred in the documents provided to us.

I will run through the portfolio statements provided to us which had errors. From the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission we received a corrigendum. There were three pages of errors in that budget statement. On page 44, there were nine errors. On page 65, there were six errors. On page 68, there was one error. In the primary industries and energy portfolio, there was one error on page 57. Of the health and family services budget statements, page 34 had four errors; page 79 had one error; page 112 had one error; page 124 had two errors; page 207 had three errors; and page 222 had three errors.

I suppose one or two errors on three or four pages is acceptable. It is possible to get it wrong. However, in her contribution, my colleague Senator Sue West drew the attention of the Senate to the social security portfolio. It is just a mass of errors. On page 34, there are three errors. Page 37 has 24 errors. Page 38 has 28 errors. Page 102 has three errors. Page 104 has two errors. Page 105 has 13 errors. Page 114 has three errors. Page 129 has three errors. Page 133 has nine errors. Page 134 has 10 errors. Page 140 has three errors. Page 142 has three errors. Page 143 has 12 errors. Page 150 has four errors. Page 153 has 16 errors. Page 160 has three errors. Page 164 has 13 errors. Bingo! That is 153 errors in total.

talk.start.para: —One big error.

—Senator Murphy is right; the budget is one big error. There are 153 errors in the social security portfolio. As I said earlier, you could forgive one, two or three errors on the odd page here and there.

speech.para: This is not the first time this has happened. As I said, Finance has to bear some responsibility. We all remember the famous mid-year economic and fiscal outlet document of 1996-97. Some debate took place between Finance and Treasury about who was responsible, but there were 170 errors in that document— which apparently was prepared by Finance. The biggest error in the mid-year economic and fiscal outlet document was a revision of the government's underlying deficit from $8.1 billion to $9.3 billion in four weeks. The whole document was littered with errors. That is not good enough.

The Department of Finance and Administration has some explaining to do. At the Finance estimates, I raised the issue in respect of the social security portfolio, and Mr Hehir drew our attention to running costs relating to the establishment of Centrelink. He also took on notice the rest of my questions about how this number of errors could occur. We are yet to receive an explanation. I understand that the department has forwarded the questions to the minister's office. We are awaiting a reply.

If we are going to conduct a fair dinkum estimates process, we have to have reliable documents. You can understand there being one or two errors, but what is going on in the Department of Finance and Administration? I understand that it has had significant staff cutbacks, but the parliament has to receive reliable documents and the level of errors that is occurring is ridiculous. I know that the Treasury bureaucrats are listening to this debate. I certainly hope they get onto Finance and find out what is going on in the department of finance for there to be that level of errors. If we are to have a thorough estimates process, we need to have accurate figures.

The second matter I want to refer to is one of major concern that arose from questioning of the Taxation Office about the tax policy in the Treasury estimates. That matter concerns the government spending approximately $10 million on a campaign to promote a new indirect tax—a goods and services tax, or the `never, ever tax' as it has become known. This $10 million will not only be spent on advertising, but also on opinion poll testing—sounding out the market. This is public money to promote a goods and services tax in the run-up to an election—whenever that may be.

That money is on top of the moneys that the Business Council of Australia is going to spend promoting a new indirect tax. You may want to correct me, Senator Watson, but the accountants association—I am not sure which one of the two bodies—also has some advertising at the present time promoting an indirect tax. So over $10 million—I think it is about $16 million in total—is being spent by three organisations, including $10 million of public funds, to promote a new indirect tax. Australia deserves better. It deserves better from Finance when it comes to estimates documents and it deserves better when it comes to a new indirect tax—the goods and services tax that the government is proposing to introduce.

A goods and services tax is complicated and costly and, Labor contends, unfair. At the last election, the Prime Minister, as I have said, promised that he would never, ever introduce a GST. He has since said that that commitment was only made for this parliamentary term and, should the government be re-elected, the GST will be introduced and, of course, it will never, ever go up. Mr Howard said:
No, there's no way that a GST will ever be part of our policy . . .
When the reporter asked him, `Never, ever?' Mr Howard said:
Never, ever. It's dead. It was killed by the voters at the last election.
In a press release on 2 May, Mr Howard said:
A GST or anything resembling it is no longer Coalition policy. Nor will it be policy at any time in the future. It is completely off the political agenda in Australia.
This promise, like so many of the current Prime Minister's cynical non-core promises, has now been broken by the `never, ever' Prime Minister.

Even the Prime Minister's backbenchers seem a little confused about what `never, ever' means. A journalist asked the National Party member for Hinkler, Mr Paul Neville, about it and asked, `For how long?' and Mr Neville replied, `Well, who knows?' Mr Chris Pyne, the Liberal member for Sturt, said, `I have no idea, but I assume that means for good.' Mr Bob Baldwin, the Liberal member for Paterson, said that it was for as long as it is practical, based on circumstances beyond their control. These are new definitions of `never, ever'.

I could talk—and I will talk on other occasions—about the proposed new broad based indirect tax. I think Mr Howard tried to use a new acronym some time ago and called it a BOBIT. He is yet to give it a name—the NET tax or the never, ever tax perhaps. Australia certainly deserves better from this Prime Minister. I went doorknocking during the fortnight of the non-sitting period. When talking to people on the doorstep and listening to their comments, I found that if you ask about the goods and services tax, even if you ask those who support a never, ever tax, `Do you honestly think it is not going to go up?', they look at you and then when you say, `Never, ever?', they smile. They certainly know what it means. And there are many other aspects of that tax.

The last issue that I want to touch on is a local matter of great concern, and in the appropriations debate we can deal with a significant range of issues. This issue concerns the proposed development of two mines on the north-west coast of Tasmania. I did put down a notice of motion last week and, regrettably, Senator Brown sought to interject very fiercely—I think you were in the chair, then, Senator Watson.

By way of background, there are two proposed magnesite mines for the north-west coast of Tasmania. One is to be owned and operated by a company called Crest Resources near West Takone, which is about 40 kilometres south of Burnie, and the other by a company called Golden Triangle, near Savage River, which, I suppose, as the crows flies, would be about 80 or 90 kilometres south of Burnie. Magnesite is the raw ore used for the production of magnesium. Magnesium is experiencing a significant increase in demand around the world. It is used in areas such as the motor vehicle industry because of its high strength and various other attributes.

I am one who does not like to overinflate the number of jobs that are likely to emerge as a consequence of these sorts of projects. However, I understand that the Crest Resources mine near West Takone will employ about 30 to 40 people directly at the mine site. Obviously that will have a flow-on impact to the rest of the community. What is important is the value-adding processing of the magnesite into magnesium metal, hopefully, in the area of Burnie-Port Latta. The total project will employ approximately 400 people, and that is dependent on gas coming onshore.

But what has been the reaction of the Green movement to these two proposals? What has been the reaction even before a pre-feasibility study has been carried out—and we will not know the result of this pre-feasibility study for at least another year or 18 months? Peg Putt, a local Green member of the Tasmanian parliament, immediately condemned the mine as being a threat to caves and what are known as karsts—magnesium upright rock pinnacles—that are in the vicinity of the mine. Ms Peg Putt alleged that the caves could be damaged by the mining project. She drew on material by a geomorphologist, Mr Kevin Kiernan, who did a study of the karsts, that the karst system could be damaged as a consequence of the mining project. This is before the pre-feasibility mining study.

Fortunately, representatives of the Savage River Caving Club have actually been into these caves—I have to say that I have not been in the caves; I don't know whether Peg Putt has been in the caves; I know there are bats in the caves. Mr Bevis Dutton of the Savage River Caving Club immediately corrected Ms Putt and said that she was using wrong information, that the area could be quarried without damage to the caves and, anyway, the caves were not of such significance that they could be rated as being of world renown. `They are intriguing but cannot be considered unique,' were their words.

As I have said, Ms Putt drew on a study of karsts by geomorphologist Mr Kevin Kiernan. Unfortunately for Ms Putt, she could not get it right the second time around either. On the following day, Mr Kiernan, whose report she had sought to rely on, said that Ms Putt's claims were incorrect. He did not believe there was a conflict with mining in the same area, given commonsense, goodwill and careful planning, and that the West Takone area could be adequately safeguarded because it involved very small reserves.

Ms Putt made one of the most startling and amazing comments by an environmentalist that I have heard during the numerous environmental debates that have occurred in recent times in Tasmania. In referring to the area where the mine may go, she said:
It has been quarried and timber harvested in the past, but it has regained a high quality wilderness.

The incredible nature of this statement leads one to ask: what has all the debate been about in Tasmania? If you can quarry and mine an area, and yet it can regain a high-quality wilderness, what is all the debate about in Tasmania? And this is Ms Putt's admission.

The important things to stress about this mine are, as I have said, that it will not endanger the cave system, it will not endanger the karst features and it will be undertaken in a multiple-use forest area which has already been extensively logged. The study by Mr Kiernan shows that mining can be compatible with the preservation of the karst features. This is a major long-term project for Tasmania which promises major economic and job creation benefits.

Ms Putt should apologise to the community in Tasmania for her fearmongering, for misleading the public on no less than two occasions and being directly contradicted by two environment experts. I am told that Mr Kiernan was a founding member of the Wilderness Society.

Tasmania, and the north-west coast in particular, needs these types of projects. Tasmania is suffering, particularly the north-west coast, from cutbacks in a whole range of areas such as aged care, health, education, and high unemployment. We need these types of economic developments in the state, not at any cost, but after a proper environmental assessment. Let us see what the pre-feasibility study says. Let us hope they get off the ground. It does not have to be rape of the environment; we can have an adequate balance between the environment and industry development. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In rising to speak on the appropriation bills, I want to make some comments about the government's telecommunications and broadcasting policies. One would have to say that, across the board over the last 2½ years, this government has got itself into a considerable mess in its telecommunications and broadcasting policy.

speech.para: Initially, the government, on the telecommunications side, had claimed a great achievement in getting its legislation to privatise one-third of Telstra through this parliament in 1996. That was a decision for which the Prime Minister of the day and the minister, Senator Alston, congratulated themselves strongly and warmly. When the privatisation of the float was completed, and about $14 billion raised from the one-third sale, it was seen as an enormous success and the Minister for Finance and Administration attempted to convince the people of Australia to support the remaining two-thirds sale of Telstra to complete the full privatisation.

But what we have found is that, since the Prime Minister announced in March this year that it was government policy to sell the remaining two-thirds, there has been a considerable backlash in public opinion. I do not think there has been any published opinion poll taken by any of the well-known polling organisations, whether at a national level or at various state or regional levels, that shows other than a minimum of at least a two to one opposition to the further sale of Telstra. What I did find interesting was that one of them—I think it was the Morgan poll—did a survey of those people who had already bought shares in the one-third sale of Telstra and even a majority of them opposed any further sale of Telstra.

There are many reasons for this, which I do not have time to go into, but today we saw one reason why a majority of Australians do not want to see Telstra fully privatised. It was the March quarterly report of the ACA—the Australian Communications Authority—on the service delivery of Telstra to the Australian public and on meeting its own commitments that it had outlined for what its service levels should be. It showed that, in the last 12 months, regarding the connection of new telephones in rural Australia, there had been nearly an 18 per cent drop in the level of service on their commitment to connect new telephones.

That is an extraordinary reduction in service and took place during the period in which Telstra was partially privatised. It certainly fits the pattern where the senior management of Telstra and the board now only ever talk about providing a good return to the shareholders—that is the number one aim of the partially privatised Telstra. The Australian public has realised that a fully privatised Telstra, dedicated to maximising profits, means that these services will further diminish in the non-metropolitan area. The reason that level of service has diminished in country areas is simple: thousands of Telstra employees have been made redundant and sacked over the past 18 months as part of the program of Telstra's management to get rid of some 25,000 of its own staff.

There are now plenty of stories from country areas that there are no staff available to meet requests from the public to have their phone connected or to have their phone fixed. That is why there is a revolt in the bush against this government on privatisation. That is why, increasingly, backbench members of the National Party and the Liberal Party in rural and regional Australia are letting the press know that they are very unhappy with the Prime Minister's unilateral decision in March of this year to sell—privatise—Telstra fully. This is an issue that the opposition will look forward to fighting most vigorously at the coming election, because we know that in the rural areas of Australia that the support from people, irrespective of their previous political allegiances, will be for the Labor Party to opposes the full privatisation of Telstra.

We also have the issue of the ABC and the way this government, and particularly the Prime Minister and the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts have treated the ABC. I will not repeat here, as I have on many occasions already, the minister's broken promises—the commitments made at the election in 1996 and the commitments made on election night after he knew he had won the election—that funding for the ABC would be maintained. That is all on the record. The $55 million a year cut in the budget has led to 800 jobs going in the ABC, with more to come. It means that many programs have been cut and have been reduced in both metropolitan and regional Australia. It has meant that the Triple J network, the ABC fine music network and other services have been reduced.

The cuts are financially horrific for the ABC but equally bad is the fact that the Prime Minister and the minister have consistently politically attacked the ABC. They have attacked it and abused it at every opportunity they get. At the recent estimates hearing of the ABC, we saw this attack taken to a new level. When the ABC appeared, the questions were immediately given to a Liberal senator, Senator Tierney, who launched into an attack for an hour and 20 minutes on the ABC's management and program content in which he accused the ABC advisory council—the independent committee which looks at charges of bias—of being in-club, in-house and part of the old boys network of the ABC.

You saw him name individual journalists for being sympathetic to the Labor Party irrespective of their long and successful professional careers. You saw statements made, separately to the estimates hearings, that people like Mr Barnett, the Prime Minister's biographer, should be appointed as a senior journalist or commentator to the ABC, not on the basis of his professional merit but on the basis that he is a supporter of the Liberal Party, contrary to all the decisions of the ABC management that people should and must be appointed according to merit.

The big challenge for the ABC is not just this government's attack on its finances but the political and ideological attack by the Prime Minister and the minister, who never miss an opportunity to criticise the ABC but do not make one word of criticism against any commentator in the commercial media, television, radio or newspapers. They make not one comment of criticism in that area about bias. It is always the ABC.

The third area is digital television, on which the debate will continue here tomorrow, I understand, if the government's program is to be believed. We think it will come back on tomorrow. Again we have an example of rushed legislation that has created considerable debate in the community and considerable differences of opinion about what it means.

This legislation that outlines the new future of broadcasting in Australia for many decades to come is being rushed through this parliament, and the government has given this digital television bill the highest priority of any piece of legislation. It is an extraordinary arrangement that this should get priority over the appropriation bill, but that was Senator Alston's wish, so we debated the digital television bill for several hours last Friday. It even gets consideration ahead of the government's plan for further privatisation of Telstra. It is an extraordinary judgment of this government to provide an arrangement whereby certain television media proprietors and their companies are dealt with very favourably. The opposition has made it clear that we support some of those decisions; others we oppose. But the government wants to rush this bill through to meet, I believe, some promise in return for political favouritism by the time of the next election.

This bill on digital television should have been allowed to lie on the table for several months as an exposure draft, when it is something so technical and so complicated. But not this government: it dealt with it in house for several months, introduced the bill, and restricted the hearings to a matter of only three weeks before the report back to the Senate. There are many still unresolved issues. That is why in the debate on digital television in the next couple of days the opposition will be moving significant amendments. And, if those amendments to make it a better bill are not accepted by the government, we will oppose it on the third reading.

I turn now to the leadership of this government. I have just outlined the government's weaknesses in my own area as shadow minister for communications. But where does this weakness come from? It comes from the present Prime Minister, who without doubt in living memory happens to be the weakest Prime Minister this country has ever seen.

talk.start.para: —That's fair.

—I must say that that is the case within living memory; I am not going to talk about the time before my living memory. I can go back to the time of John Gorton, Billy McMahon, Harold Holt and even Bob Menzies. When John Howard was elected Prime Minister, I said, `Although I disagree with him ideologically, he is a man with very considerable political experience both in government and opposition. He has been around a long time. He will certainly know how to handle the processes of government.' It is clear that the job is too big for him. We now have a Prime Minister who actually makes Billy McMahon look positively good in comparison—and Billy McMahon I can remember. But John Howard is incapable of providing the leadership that this country so desperately yearned for, because he is without vision; he can only look backwards and hanker for the days of his own childhood and teenage days of the 1950s when he thought Sir Robert Menzies as Prime Minister provided the golden age of Australian Liberal Party rule.

speech.para: We have found that he cannot articulate any vision for the future. He cannot provide comfort, even though he said he wanted Australia to be relaxed and comfortable. He cannot provide any sense of vision for the future that gives some sense of purpose to the Australian nation. Every time he attempts it, he gets it wrong, he sounds backward and mealy-mouthed, and he is always pessimistic. I have never seen a Prime Minister look so pessimistic, even when he is announcing so-called good news. This Prime Minister is not able to give any sense of hope or optimism to the Australian people. I think that is why, at the next election, the issue of leadership will be one of the most important between the two major parties. I have no doubt that that will be a major issue.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the extraordinary example of how the Prime Minister thought he could provide a vision for the future by his endorsement of an unfunded project with no feasibility study, the so-called Melbourne to Darwin railway line. Anyone reading the transcript of that press conference would have thought, `This is something more suited to Monty Python or a university revue satire of politicians.' And what did John Howard say at that press conference? He said, `This is a project with great vision, subject to feasibility studies, subject to this, subject to that.'

When the project was unveiled at the press conference, a map of Australia was produced which showed the train line zigzagging through all the critical electorates of inland Australia that are now under threat. We saw that it seemed to go through every country town in inland Australia that wanted to have a new train line. The promoter of the train line, Mr Crompton, said at the press conference, `What is $8½ billion in cost? That is just an 8, a 5, and a few 0s.' He actually sounded like a One Nation supporter saying, `Just print more money to pay for any project.'

He also announced, `If $8½ million is too much we could build a single track for $5 billion, because we now have new technology. The trains can be on the same track coming towards each other at a speed of 500 kilometres an hour and, with new technology, they will miss each other by half a kilometre.' You would not want to be out selling the fact that passenger trains can be on the same track coming towards each other. Those are the sorts of concepts which were let loose at this press conference and which the Prime Minister endorsed. Since the announcement, the Prime Minister's involvement has been quite rightly criticised, and it has become a political cartoonist's dream world. We have seen wonderful cartoons appearing with maps of Australia and train lines looping the loop and zigzagging all over it, trying to find which electorate missed out on the train line under this project.

This Prime Minister does not understand that vision and the future of Australia require a Prime Minister and a person in a leadership position who is able to articulate a broad view about the sort of society we want in Australia, about being inclusive. This Prime Minister is incapable of giving any idea of how to be inclusive of all Australian people. He believes that the political circumstances that serve him best are to create division, to pick on different groups in the community and make them the whipping boys for the other part of the community.

That is the style of this Prime Minister's leadership. It is a disgraceful leadership. I never thought he would be this bad. When he was elected I thought that because of his experience he would be a conservative Prime Minister with whom the Labor Party would ideologically disagree on many issues, but he would have a concept of how to be a Prime Minister for all Australia. He has sadly failed in every way. He proves the old adage: you may well be an excellent minister, you may well be an excellent political performer in parliament, but it is a big step to go from there to being Prime Minister.

In the past, on both the Labor Party and the Liberal Party sides, most leaders who have become Prime Minister have been able to make the jump. John Howard has not been able to make the big jump up to being Prime Minister. He cannot overcome his pettiness, his divisiveness and the fact that everything he does is seen as a political advantage in the narrowest sense. That is why, at this coming election, leadership will be a major issue. We in the Labor Party only two years ago believed it would be very difficult to win an election after only one term in opposition. This Prime Minister now makes that a very real possibility. We look forward to winning the next election because of the mayhem he has created in this country through his weak leadership and through letting the Hanson party get up a head of steam, which ironically is now decimating the Liberal Party and the National Party.

I congratulate Senator Ron Boswell for today getting stuck into the One Nation Party and all its mad right-wing backers. I say to Senator Boswell: if you are going to be fair dinkum about that speech, get the Prime Minister of this country to unilaterally and unequivocally say that the Liberal and National parties will give their preferences last to One Nation in every electorate across Australia. Senator Boswell says that, Mr Costello says that, Mr Downer says that, Senator Hill says that; the one person who does not say that is the Prime Minister of this country because he is a weak leader.

The irony is that, because of his weakness, One Nation is now cannibalising and eating out the coalition. And isn't it a sweetness in one sense, an irony, that he thought he would let it loose to do damage to the Labor Party in 1996, but it is now doing damage and destroying his own leadership, as it should. It proves the old adage: if you are a weak leader, in the end you are destroyed by your own weakness. If he had been a strong leader and had had the courage to take on One Nation two years ago, his own leadership would not now be in the major process of being destroyed from either within the Liberal Party or in the electorate. We look forward in the coming few months to the election of the first Kim Beazley Labor government.
